The entire place was very clean though a little dated.  The person that helped us at the front desk was friendly and told us how to get to our room.  We took the elevator to the 11th floor and entered our room.  The color scheme was terrible but it was clean and the room and bathroom were a good size.  It was acceptable though I was a little disappointed.  I expected something that rivaled the Hyatt Regency we stayed in the night before in San Antonio.  While the beds were comfortable, the pillows weren't.  I also didn't get a very good nights sleep due to the noise from inside and outside.  We heard a lot of street noise and maybe even a train.  I also heard a lot of noise from the hall way.  Not only that but the toilet was loud and would run for several minutes after being flushed.  The only other complaint is that the room was too bright.  It looked like someone used a voltage of light bulb that wasn't appropriate for the lamps.  I also wanted to mention that WiFi in your room costs $12.95 per night and the valet parking is $25.  I didn't use the WiFi so I can't speak to its speed, however, the staff was very friendly and quick in getting my car even though the hotel parks it 5-6 blocks away.   I primarily booked this place because of its proximity to Brick Town.  I would say that its 3-4 blocks away and I'm not sure I'd want to walk it at night.  Fortunately, they have a limo that will drop you off anywhere within a mile of the hotel from 3 PM to Midnight.  That's a nice touch.  In the end, I'm not sure that I would stay in this hotel again.  I've certainly stayed in much worse places but for the price, I had high expectations.Hmm...Mrs. Eva and I stay at Renaissance usually twice a year, usually for a convention or board meeting.The place is very nice, service is good, lobby and bar are nice places to gather. Rooms are always clean and detailed.The rooms are starting to show a little wear and it's about time for a makeover. It's a little pricey if you just consider the room price, but the amenities help make it a little easier to deal with the price.All in all, still a nice place to stay.I have mixed reviews about this hotel. We originally got the hotel b/c our friend was an artist at a music festival in Oklahoma City. When we were greeted and when we left the staff was very nice to us. However, the second day staying at the hotel, some guard had the audacity to start assuming that we were going to cause problems even though we had no history of starting any in the hotel. He even knocked on our door and warned us not to think about fooling around that night even though we hadn't at all! Idk about you but the hotel should always treat everyone with respect until given a reason otherwise and in this case I felt there was no reason. I felt patronized honestly. Also the food was horrible and expensive. But the waiter was really nice. Overall I probably wouldn't stay here again since they have a bias against younger people even though we should be treated the same as long as we behave since we are paying just as much as anyone else and are a customer regardless. However it wasn't terrible.WORST HOTEL EXPERIENCE EVER!My guy had a work conference there so he invited me to come for a mini getaway. He upgraded the hotel room since I'd be there so we ended up on the executive level (required key card access to get on the floor). No one ever mentioned that one of the amenities that came with that was a free continental breakfast. We found out on morning 3 so we were not very happy. The cleaning service was slow. I had to call down to the front for more towels b/c room service hadn't shown up by 2 pm. Then the operator tells me that they have until 3:30 pm to clean my room. The towels finally showed up 45 min later after a call from me and my guy. BTW - the actually cleaning lady didn't show up till almost 4 pm. My guy was upset and asked for the mgr who didn't answer and NEVER returned his call. You can only valet which is $25 a night. And we were there 5 nights so total that up. One of the water ponds downstairs was dirty and smelled horrible. The TV kept freezing up or losing signal the last two days we were there.And the thing that topped it off was that you could only have free wifi access on the 1st floor. For $165 + a night, we should have wifi access. To get wifi access above the 1st floor, cost $13 a day. I've stayed in hotels that range from $75 to $300 a night and know what to expect but I can honestly say that I had a better experience @ a $99 a night hotel than at this one. And we met quite a lot of people who felt the same way. Everyone said that if they had known ahead of time, they would have rather stayed further out.....AMEN!We would never ever stay at a Renaissance Hotel again. We were happy to say goodbye to that place. Seriously.Beautiful atrium lobby. I didn't stay here, so I can't comment on the rooms. We did have a meeting in one of the meeting rooms and it was nice. The Hotel is directly across the street from the Convention Center so quite convenient. Unfortunately, they were all booked so I had to stay out by the airport.This is the worst hotel experience I have ever had although only some had to do with the hotel itself.  Rented a room and asked for an upper floor so it would be quieter.  Was put in a room next to the ice machine and elevators, not what I had in mind, but fine.  Went to the Thunder game and had an excellent time.  This hotel is within walking distance of lots of restaurants and venues.  Around 2:30 is when the neighbors came home.  Slamming doors, loud talking and ridiculously loud sex.  It went on for HOURS!  People came and went and on it continues.  Called down to desk and they sent security up after hour 4 but this only briefly deterred them and they started back up again shortly.  The walls are incredibly thin and there was not a word or a sound we didn't hear.  The hotel was not full but did not offer to move us or them or take any real action to shut them up.  Neighbors on the other side complained as well.  I have never paid so much for a hotel and gotten so little sleep in my life.  Housekeeping knocked on the door at 8am wanting to clean!  Um, no!  I had just fallen asleep.  Then the hotel bill came it was correct on the print out but after checking my bank statement later that day I realize they overcharged me by $75.  Room is nice but not worth the price.  I'm just glad this isn't a time I took my son with me.  HorribleThis might be what you're looking for, but it wasn't for me. I spend a lot of time alone in hotels, so internet access is a must. I don't know how good the paid internet is, but the free internet is worthless.  It's kind of fancy, but lacks in amenities. I'm going back to the Residence Inn the first chance I get.Slip into a robe.  Get comfortable.  I have things to say about this place.First off, Israel greeted us with more honest to goodness hospitality than my family has greeted me after three years of not seeing me (I exaggerate).  But the man went above and beyond to find off street parking for us (parked it), explained things to us in the room, and made sure we were just taken care of.  Not the usual treatment you receive.Jesse?  Oh Jesse.  Was he really talking about how the universe started with my boyfriend on the way to Bricktown on our complimentary shuttle (anything is free within one mile of the hotel apparently)?  I tuned out most of that conversation.  But you can definitely get the shuttle bus or Cade "the driver" (yes, per the card) up until midnight daily gratis.We had a slight problem with our room.  But we were taken care of immediately by who I assume was the same person who checked us in... Chris?  If you haven't figured it out, i am in fact trying to work on my name recognition.  Goodness, if I were to name everybody at this hotel that hooked it up it would be like the first day of kindergarten with everybody listing their names!  This is a great little hotel with very kind employees and a very modern decorated hotel in the heart of OKC.  Stay here and you will not be disappointed by the service that you receive.This Renaissance is completely worth it. It is located six blocks from the Oklahoma City Bombing Memorial, a stone's throw from Bricktown, the new hip place to be, and the amenities are working! While the rooms are nice, the bar well appointed, and the finish outs of the hotel are all together nice, the best part of the experience was the concierge. I asked if I could have a shuttle for some guest to make it to the memorial and back within an hour. He told me to meet him at the concierge desk when I was ready. We rendezvoused as planned, and he had a stretch limousine ready for us - for no charge. It was a courtesy of the hotel! What?! I looked pretty good in front of the VIPs, though I did not intend to do so. Thanks, Renaissance people!We spent our anniversary here. We were on the 14th floor and the room was huge! I was concerned because the ice and soda machine were next to our room but noise was not a problem. There's a lot to like about this hotel but there were a few things I wasn't too happy with:1. There was no fridge in the room. There was a place for one in the tv cabinet but it was just empty space. I called the desk and they offered to bring us one. Seriously? In a hotel like this there should be a fridge.2. WIFI in the room was $12.95. OK, but when my wife tried to use her laptop that would have been another $12.95! GRRR! To be fair, there is free WIFI in the lobby and the business center.3. Our room had a flat screen TV but it was kind of small for that room, probably a 32 inch screen which we had to angle to view it from the bed.On the good side, the staff is friendly and check-in was very fast. Although valet parking is availble you can enter the parking building off Broadway and pay $5.00 for the night. You can walk to the hotel using the covered skybridge and not be subjected to the elements. Breakfast was included and it was very good--omelets made to order, lots of fresh fruit, pastries and just about anything else you could want. The beds were comfortable enough and we requested extra pillows were they promptly brought to us.Overall we enjoyed our stay and the hotel has more plusses than minuses..I've stayed at another Renaissance Hotel which was why I had no problem booking a priceline reservation for the one in OKC. I wish I hadn't for a few reasons. I had forgotten that Renaissance hotels cater to corporate travels with expense accounts and so charges $12.95 per laptop in the rooms. They also charge $25 for valet, and unlike the other hotels in bricktown, do not have their own garage. I really, really wish I'd known that.Now, Even with that, I still probably would have given it 3.5 stars. The pool, while small, is nice, and there's a nice little workout room next to it. They also have, I believe, a sauna. Free wifi is available in the lobby, but I do wish that they had more comfortable couches. The only comfortable ones I found were in the bar and that closes at night. I was staying in room 621. I'm writing this because of specific complaints with that room. The fire alarm kept chirping which I assume had to do with a low battery. It could have just started chirping or it could have been chirping for the last day. It was a hassle to wait twenty minutes for the maintenance guy to come fix it as I'd had a long drive and just wanted to sleep. The front desk woman was very helpful though each time I called wondering where the maintenance guy was. The room itself was nice enough. The problem was that the furniture was a bit banged up. The worst part was that the decorative finial on the headboard had been knocked off previously, and instead of it being fixed (or hell, even glued) some genius decided to take little nails and not nail it in so much as create a little cage of nails where the head of the nails kept the finial in place. Really Renaissance? I've seen one star motels that would never have something so shady looking.Still, it was quiet and the maid service didn't bother me in the morning.Want to know what really bothered me? My car was broken into in their gated, video-surveillanced lot. But I think the manager said they didn't do security walk-throughs, which I don't understand. Why isn't there a security guy there walking about at night? Three cars were broken into, and according to the hotel manager who was very apologetic and talked with me while I inspected my car, it was mostly change that was stolen. So a crackhead probably walked in after a valet brought a car in and either hunted for unlocked cars or somehow disabled my car alarm AND unlocked my door (I don't think so.) I feel very lucky that I didn't have a window broken or something like that but I'm bothered that my car probably wasn't armed with my key fob. Also, my wallet (I had taken out my credit card and ID the night before but had forgotten to put it back in my purse instead leaving it in the center console when shopping) had been gone through and spilled over the front of my car. My glove box had been open. Stuff in the back of my car was rifled through. Luckily, I had brought up everything with me that I couldn't stand to lose but still. I had some prepaid cards (there was only a little bit of a balance on both) stolen (which the manager said they would reimburse which was nice) but as the days go by since then, I'm disgusted. I can't even look at my wallet because the creep thief stole all my change from that as well as a large half-dollar I carried around with me and refused to spend because my boyfriend gave it to me. I'm going to get a new wallet. The manager had told me that the thief had even gone through one of the other victim's suitcases and left everything laying out. I cannot imagine having to look at clothes that had been pawed through like that. In the big scheme of things, it's a small crime-- nothing of great value was stolen, and nothing was really harmed. However I was still charged for valet service.I wasn't offered any comping whatsoever and I didn't ask because I just wanted to get out of there. I found the people that worked there very nice, but the high up-charging for things that you could get for free or extremely less at other upscale places, coupled with shady "fix its" in the rooms, and having my car broken into with very little in the was of "going above and beyond" to fix a very egregious occurrence leads me to say I am never saying at this Renaissance again. I'm very disappointed in the Renaissance business model.I really enjoyed this hotel and hope I will get to go back soon. I was surprised at how little noise we heard from outside and the interior courtyard. The lobby is beautiful and the ponds and fountains give off just enough white noise to create a relaxing environment. Great fitness center and a huge indoor pool. I also love that they have a Starbucks coffee shop with a decent pastry selection and a pretty large gift/sundries shop. The room was very clean and I really enjoyed the chaise lounge in front of the window with a view of Bricktown. Good sized bathroom and closet. I would definitely recommend valet parking- once they take your car you can walk to Bricktown. The valets were amazing- they were hustling in 100+ degree heat and still very courteous.I love this hotel for many reasons.  It's always clean, the hotel has a really cool style and decor, the staff is extremely courteous, and the rooms are not super expensive (especially for what you get).  The BEST BEST BEST thing (and I'm pretty sure this goes for all of them) is that it's a free shuttle to and from the airport.  They also have a free shuttle to accommodate their guests in the evening, which not only help's if you aren't familiar with the area, but as to not drink and drive.  I have always received great suggestions from the staff as to where to go, even one time offering their free limo service to all my friends (a somewhat motley crew staying there for the Flaming Lips New Year's show) the night before New Year's.  The limo driver even picked us up from the restaurant afterwards.  Oh, and if you go mostly anywhere in the OKC area and order a ginger ale....I GUARANTEE you will get Coke and Sprite mixed instead.  I didn't believe it myself til my husb did it twice.Regarding "Joe L." 's response to my recent yelp....THANK YOU for making my point.That 13 dollars per day not only pays for internet, but for "unlimited local phone calls".WHAT A JOKE!  Roadside motels have had that for free since 1972.and "unlimited long distance calls"??  WHO USES THAT IN THE ERA OF CELL PHONES?And as for your comment of providing free "wireless internet service in the public areas of our hotel"....  So if I want to google the local movie listings I need to get dressed, leave my room on the 14th floor, ride down the elevator, go to the lobby, google my movie listing, WRITE IT DOWN since I won't be able to take it back to the room with me, take an elevator ride back up to the 14th floor, fumble for my key card, get undressed & crawl back in bed where I was to begin with, JUST to know what movies are showing after I catch a few ZZZ's.  Brilliant.  Rennaissance REALLY seems to understand their customers and the nature of travel.Here is a NOVEL idea:  instead of charging me $250 for that fancy room & then SHAFTING me like a sailor in Shanghai, how about simply charging me $263 for the room, and then giving me the same basic service I can get at the Motel Six.  Hell, charge me THREE HUNDRED and sixty three dollars-- I don't care!  But ripping me off over 13 phucking dollars per day for something that is a BASIC need of travel is SO INSULTING, SO INFURIATING, and SO UNCONCIONABLE, that my brain can barely process it.The marketing people at Rennaissance corporate are idiots.Great service. Nice rooms.Eat at the hotel bar. Was very good meal. Average beer selection, but very friendly staff.They are close to everything and have a van to take you around if needed.Sadly this was a very poor experience. As strong Marriott brand loyalists we have been to quite a few Marriott brand hotels including other Renaissance hotels.  This one was by far the worst experience we've had. To start, the valet pricing is standard and we had no issue with the $25/day. The problem is that the hotel does not have their own lot anywhere near the hotel. The valet has to drive 4plus blocks to park then literally runs back. The process works the other way as well. Over the three days it took on average 30 minutes for our vehicle to be brought to the hotel once we requested it. The hotel looked nice, old but nice. We were given a room on the 11th floor which, aside from the roof of the adjacent convention center, had a great view of the city. The room was large but very plain. There was no safe or fridge and the temperature was either way too hot or too cold. (We were continually adjusting the thermostat to try to even it out to no avail). The furniture was outdated and had black grease stains on the arms of the chair. We gladly began to settle in. It was then we began hearing the doors of the rooms along the hall slamming. The latch mechanism in the doors are so stiff it requires that they be slammed hard to get them to close and latch. This continued on the whole time we were there at all hours. We changed and headed to Bricktown (Fantastic!!!!!) and soon found that the sidewalk to Bricktown was under construction (as was much of the city apparently) so we had to walk along the edge of the hotel wall where the sidewalk still had some remaining bricks. It was a one foot in front of the other walk so I can imagine what would happen if someone had a drink or two.....:)  Over-all, the hotel was sub-par compared to what we have come to expect from Marriott brand hotels.Stayed here for one night and attended a meeting in one of their conference rooms. Came home to see that they had charged my card $178.61???? The company had paid for our rooms. When I called he said they do that incidentals and the charge would come off in 3-5 business days. The room wasn't even worth that price for one night. Outdated 80's decor and charge happy once they get a card. Oh not to mention no free wi-fi.
review_content_40: I forgot to mention that they have free shuttle to the airport. Good $30-$40 savings...Very clean, very friendly, & very cheap thanks to priceline!  God bless Shatner!If it had a self parking it would get 5 stars!Nice facility. Not overly friendly staff - I just feel those of us in this business have to go over and above. Navigators were great though. I stayed 2 nights - I didn't have my room cleaned until after 5:30!Great hotel. The valet/bell service is the best part. They really go above and beyond to take care of you. Take a limo downtown and ask for recs on places to eat.Great hotel.  Staff were very friendly.  They remembered my name after the first week i was there.  I suppose that when you are there 4 days out of the week for months they should know your name.  Room service was quick and delicious.  Staff was very attentive to my needs and always upgraded me when there was availability.  If i go to Oklahoma again i would definitely stay here again.I love this hotel. Stayed here twice and was always impressed with the service. The fitness center rocks, along with the location and price (government rate). The valet parking was super fast once you called them. My only peeve is that the chef should be alittle more courteous in the morning.Nice  clean hotel.  The staff are not unfriendly, but not especially attentive.  It is quite convenient, especially if you have a meeting or conference  at the convention center that it is connected to by the sky bridge.  There are a few restaurants within walking distance, which is good because you will want to valet park, even though it is quit expensive.  If you don't valet park, the parking lot is 4 blocks away.  The food at the restaurant is just okay, but the service was not that great.  They do have a shop with Starbucks, but the pastries are not very good, and of course everything is overpriced.Hotel had a bad kitchen fire at 4am.  Guest were alerted via intercom recording to exist the nearest stairway. There was on security guard holding the door for us at the ground floor exit but no one checking/directing guests long the staircase or the smoky hallway.  My colleague, who has arthritis and walks with a cane was unfortunately placed on the nonetheless floor.  He had such a hard time coming down 9 flights during the emergency. No one assisted him except for other compassionate guests.  Needless to say, fire fighter put out the fire, and we were asked to come back into the smoky hotel and into our rooms.  10 minutes later fire alarm went off again throwing guests into panicky.  NO STAFF WAS THERE to inform guests it was false alarm... some guests exited the hotel, other Guests have to find that out from a fire fighter walking around premise.  The fire fighters were more courteous and were more helpful in event of hotel emergencies.  During the whole ordeal the staffs all pretended it never happen.  No one apologized for the early morning disturbance, no one bothered to ask if they can make the stay more pleasant.  Perhaps management needs to review current disaster preparedness plan.  If it were not for complimentary shuttle/limo, i would rate it lower comparing it to Motel 8 experience.  Free guest wifi though, ok enough to surf web and check emails.I just spent 4 nights and 5 days at the Renaissance Hotel while I was attending the Red Earth Festival across the street at the Cox Convention Center, and I think this has to be one of the better hotels I've stayed at in my time (and I travel a LOT). The maid service was excellent except for my final sunday when she forgot to replenish my bathroom soaps and shampoos (luckily I had some left from the days prior). The staff was friendly and courteous except for the night desk guy who asked me, to my face (when I had lost my key card), "Are you SURE you're staying here?" even after I'd recited my partner rooms that were all under the same company name. That's where I'm dinging the hotel a star because he was just being rude for no reason.For breakfast, the buffet was great, with lots of fresh fruit, and cooks who can cook an egg to order like nobody's business. The indoor pool and hot tub were excellent, and well maintained, and the excercise room was small, but largely unused this weekend, probably because their was a convention of portly cowboys meeting at the hotel.(and this led to tons of jokes about the Indian arts and dancing convention going on across the street and how on Sunday there was going to be a cheoreographed cowboys versus indians fight between both warring factions), but I digress...The bar was reasonably priced and has games and either movies or sports shows playing, and even coin-op video games and a smoking patio for those of use who don't do either sports or TV as much. There's a game room and I got the high score on the stand-up Millipede arcade game, 92,000! Beat that!The final plus was the restaurant waitress, Nina, who took care of all of us like an absolute pro, jumping to get us coffee, juices, and everything else like she was psychic! That woman deserves a raise!the hotel is fairly well maintained and the rooms are comfortable. Normally I don't eat in the hotel restaurant for dinner, but the food here was exceptionally good. The cab driver said that this was the second best hotel in the city next to the Hilton. I didn't see the Hilton but I heard it was nice.Brunch was poor quality. Few selections.  Friendly, but inept service.  Someone needed to clean up and replenish the dessert table.  We were expecting something more for $29 per person.I spent a couple of weeks at this hotel while working on a project in Oklahoma City.  My client was in the building next door so I did not have to rent a car.  There are lots of restaurants within walking distance. The rooms are large and clean. The beds are the new Marriott overstuffed ones that are very comfortable.   I also enjoyed the concierge lounge that my Platinum status grants me access to.The gym has dumbells up to 50 lbs and plenty of cardio machines such as treadmills and stationary bikes.  This worked out since I could not find a good gym within walking distance so I did all of my workouts here which brings me to my funny traveling story.After working out on a Monday evening I went up to the concierge lounge to get a snack.  Since I had been up early traveling and I had done a hard workout I decided to reward myself with a brownie.  Since the hotel was not crowded I was given a suite.  However, the couches did not face the TV.  I decided to adjust the TV while I held the plate with the brownie on it.  However, it turned out the TV was not screwed down and it started to fall.  Since I had brownie in my other had I could not catch the tv in time to stop it from falling to the ground.  As the TV was falling my plate when with it and the brownie was splattered all over the room.I heard the TV pop as it hit the floor so I knew it was a goner.  I picked the TV up and check to see if maybe it survived.  No such luck.  So I called down to the front desk and explained my situation.  It was kind of embarassing.  The Hotel Tech came up installed a new TV (did not screw it down though).The funny part is that two days later the band Def Leppard showed up.  The hotel was not that crowded so it was basically Def Leppard and me staying the hotel.  Turns out that rock stars travel just like business travelers.   They meet up in the lobby before going to dinner.  They stop at the ATM machine and they work out in the fitness room (Vivian Campbell was on the treadmill while I was working out).  The main difference is that they show up with 10 tour buses.At the end of the day I got a good road story to tell (although I have not told this story in some time).Compared to the Sheraton across the street, this place is fantastic.Very nice hotel lobby area, great staff and decent food. I did not get to walk around much due to my short time there but I would definitely go back and pay the extra $20 or so over Sheraton. Valet parking here is a pain - it is far away so it takes 10 min to get your car.Very nice hotel, comfortable beds and tastefully decorated.  Valet parking is the only hotel option ($25/night), but there is a perfectly fine parking garage connected to a skybridge that is across the street from the hotel which charges only $7/night.  If I ever find myself in OKC again, I will stay here.

review_content: Amazing hotel and service. Best location ever, just a couple blocks from the stadium.Met and exceeded all my expectations! Must stay here when in OKC.Just came from a Junior League event that was here, and want to go back! For starters, I love a good hotel, with retro throwbacks, mixed with modern style. Everything from the food to the service was on point this evening. I was so impressed with their spread of yummy bites -- that included popcorn with bacon salt (yes, bacon salt), and Cajun spices, to name a few. Their antipasto tray had the thickest salami I've ever seen! It was savory and soo good. Being at the Colcord, and seeing the festive holiday lights made me desperately want to renew my wedding vows, haha. There's so many wonderful views of the surrounding downtown Okie area you get.I'm trying to find an excuse for my husband and I to go back!Stayed here for a couple of days while on business. It is a beautiful Historic Hotel with exceptional service. The rooms are huge!! It is nicely situated  across from the Botanical Gardens and only couple blocks walk from Bricktown which has the Dodgers AAA farm club and since I am from SoCal and a die hard Dodger fan that was the icing on the cake. Also while I was there my husband surprised me with flowers in my room. Thank you to Patrice the hotel operator/concierge for assisting my husband in that endeavor. I am forever appreciative. Lastly the hotel restaurant/bar... Flint... was delicious! Thank you to Hunter and Tristan for your company and amazing service!  I look forward to staying here in the future on more business trips and with my family.Apologies to the Skirvin, but I've got my new go to hotel when I am in need of a room in downtown OKC.  I arrived Friday evening.  The valet was crowded, but they get you through quickly.  Now, it's $25 a night to valet.  I know a lot of people will balk at that, but look around.  You're in downtown OKC, there's not much self parking available.  Also, they are very quick getting your vehicle; just call from your room and usually it just takes a couple of minutes.  I think it's well worth it.The check in process was quick and the employee was very friendly.  I had a K size corner room, which apparently are larger.  I had a nice sitting area, a small work station, and a good sized flat screen.  The bed was very comfortable, as are the linens and pillows.  Very good quality.  Importantly, each side of the bed had 2 very accessible electrical outlets.  Too many places tuck them away to the point you have to move the bed.  This annoys me to no end.  But, very easy access at Colcord.  Free and reliable wifi, which is a plus.The bathroom is large, with a separate sink, then a large soaking tub/shower, then a water closet.  I really liked the toiletries, and I don't usually care about them at a hotel.  The shower is large, but it doesn't close completely off.  There is a sort of half wall of glass, then the rest of the shower.  So, cold air could get in while you were showering.  It was aesthetically nice, but functionally not so much.  The room service ends at 11:00 and is Flint, which is an above average downtown restaurant.  Vast is a very short walk as well, as Colcord is connected to Devon Tower.  Every employee I encountered was very friendly and constantly (but not annoyingly) asking if I needed anything.  Colcord offers above average rooms, a nice in house restaurant in Flint, and very friendly service.  There's a reason it's go so many 5 star reviews.  Definite return.We stayed at this hotel while attending a tradeshow at the nearby convention center. This hotel is wonderfully charming!The Colcord is a very charming boutique hotel! The staff is sooooo very amazingly hospitable and helpful! They offer a free coffee/tea service each morning, and they are very prompt with the delivery so incredibly kind.  The rooms are very clean, they have a nice ambiance and they are very spacious. The beds are quite comfy. The a/c was great! (very thankful for this!) Everyone is so prompt to respond to requests. They also have a shuttle that will happily take you around the downtown area, and then pick you up and bring you back. I definitely recommend The Colcord!My wife is staying there and I wanted to surprise her with flowers since she is on a business trip. That is when I had the pleasure of speaking with Patrice. She helped me find a florist close by and once they arrived Patrice had someone put the flowers in my wife's room. Let me say living out in California that type of customer service is rare to find. Patrice's friendly attitude and willingness to help was a great experience. I just wanted to say thank you for all of your help Patrice!!!!Stayed here the night prior to the OKC 1/2 marathon in April. A beautiful hotel, spacious and wonderful room, comfortable bed, and a decent sized bathroom.The service was beyond excellent. Every single encounter we had was completely courteous and classy. My wife and I were very pleased, and will return to this hotel without question. Specifically of note - we appreciated the cookies delivered to our room, and the 3pm late checkout for runners in the race. As i am a slow runner, this was awesome!The only (minor) detractors were the small lobby, and the weak water pressure from the shower. It wasn't terrible, but I like the water pouring out if possible. Great hotel, fair price, we'll be back.You would be hard pressed to beat the Colcord experience...even spending considerable more money!  This is my "go-too" place anytime I am in the area...I booked this room for a conference I was attending. The group I was going with had reservations at a host hotel. Thankfully, I had to book somewhere else, because I got to stay here!!!The Colcord is a super nice hotel. The staff is amazingly hospitable. They offer a free coffee/tea service each morning.  The rooms are nice and spacious. The beds are great. The a/c works like a charm. Everyone is so prompt to respond to requests. The shuttle bus will happily take you around the downtown area. I only wish this exquisite, boutique hotel had other locations in other cities. But that would probably ruin the amazing service. This place is highly recommended. Flint is a restaurant in the hotel. Eat chicken bites.It is a sad thing, when money is worth more than a good review. The Colcord did my room block and rehearsal dinner. We booked out 90 room nights with them, 85% of which, we had to guarantee in order to not pay a penalty, and over $6,000 on the rehearsal dinner.We were told that we were receiving a significant discount on our room rates at $179 a night. But as we got closer to the date, we had more and more guests telling us that they were opting to stay at other hotels because they Colcord rate for our room block, was actually MORE than what the Colcord was offering online to other guests not with the wedding. $169 is how much it cost online. Knowing that the hotel didn't HAVE to do anything (signed contract), I reached out thinking that they would at least meet the $169. After all, we had heard that their front desk was telling people to use their AAA discount INSTEAD OF OUR ROOM BLOCK.Not only were they unwilling to save our guests $10 a night, the General Manager, Blayne, was in fact, the rudest person I have spoken to in ages. He was curt, unprofessional, and inhospitable. In the end, he lowered the rate to $174, which meant our guests paid $5 more a night, than other guests of the hotel. NOT what you want when you reserve 90 freaking room nights, and pay thousands for an event.Our rehearsal dinner was great. The staff ought to teach upper management a thing or two about hospitality, because those people are the only reason I am giving ANY stars. And the rooms are beautiful. Had it not been for Blayne, I'd be giving a much better review.They also charged all my bridesmaids for their rooms after we explicitly instructed them to use the card the rooms were guaranteed under.In the end, That $5 per night cost them a good review. They cared more about overcharging MY WEDDING GUESTS and getting their $450 (total for all the rooms), than doing the right thing. Their General Manager has no business working in hospitality in a state that PRIDES ITSELF on how accommodating they are.EDIT: See Blane's response below. That's his takeaway from this review y'all. No need to improve customer service at the Colcord! Brides beware!If you have never stayed, you have no idea what you are missing. Positively the best (my wife would say romantic, but I'm a guy) place to stay in the city. Great rooms, great staff; historic yet like being at a fancy home you don't have.    Restaurant is great!    Have to admit, I miss the old oyster bar that used to be there but time moves on...On second thought, don't stay here. It just leaves more room for us!This Hotel went ABOVE AND BEYOND! My Wife and I had a reservation to stay here but upon check-in they told us that their system had overbooked the hotel and we didn't have a room there, but they had already made us reservations for a new and fantastic hotel across the street, "ALOFT". They drove us over to the hotel, checked us in and paid for our room, valet costs, room service, and all taxes. The front office manager named Clara made sure that everything was taken care of. Colcord or the staff didn't have to take care of this mistake this well, but it goes to show how much they truly value their customers. I will be returning to this hotel upon my next visit to OK City. I would strongly recommend Colcord and Aloft to all travelers.And by the way the "Aloft" hotel was nice, new, and a very upscale hotel.This hotel is as stunning on the inside as it is out. Located in the heart of Oklahoma City, this is a staple that is rich in history and style. Staying here will impress everyone.Checking in was a breeze before heading up to the room. THE ROOM. Ya, that deserved it's own sentence. For a downtown hotel, the amount of space in the room was incredible. The bed was sublimely comfortable and there was even a fancy pants chair that you could easily nap in next to the bed by a window overlooking the city.The shower had eucalyptus strung around and made me feel like I was bathing like a greek goddess.Best part of my stay? Complimentary morning coffee delivery. CHYA. I know my coffee, and this stuff was good.Thank you, Colcord for a memorable stay!We decided to take a spur of the moment trip down to the city for Christmas. At first glance, the hotels exterior is not as impressive as some of the larger hotels. However, the interior is beautiful and modern. I loved the set-up of the standard king room. We usually upgrade to the deluxe or a suite but due to the nature of this trip, this was all that was available. The little private hallway entry to the room was impressive. In addition, the separation of the sink and bath area made the room seem much larger. Overall the hotel was very clean and the service was great! Their restaurant, Flint was also superb.So..Im not the "yelp" kind of guy. I hate writing reviews and am extremely lazy.Recently I was forced to OKC for two weeks of work. This would be my second such trip in a year and I was dreading it based on my previous stay at the Sheraton. The Colcord changed my tune and changed it quickly.Everything was perfect. From the time I checked in...excuse me if i mess up some names...Hanna was fantastic and ensured I was happy with my days travels. My wakeup call was a knock on the door and a fresh pot of coffee, Great touch! The valet always had my car ready, or almost always, ready for me to leave as I got downstairs each morning at 645. When I returned, Flint, would always have a drink and some good conversation. Even the turndown service was nice...providing a forecast and cookie. HA.The hotel was nice enough that instead of dreading my next trip to OKC ill be looking forward to it!Stay here whenever I'm in town. Just got home from spending the weekend at the Colcord and it couldn't have been better. Had reservations and my girlfriend and I showed up from a bike ride we had been on that morning. They stored the bikes for us for the weekend, staff is great and very courteous. Showed up early and they got our room ready while we waited in the lobby. Coffee delivered to our room the next morning at the designated time. Gave the valet our number when checked out and went to breakfast. The car was waiting with the luggage loaded along with our bikes. Love these guys and can't wait to come back.We had a wonderful stay here recently. It was especially fun since I used to office in this building before it was a hotel, and I'd always wanted to stay here as a guest. Even though I had built it up for a long time, it exceeded my expectations. We had a handful of rooms for family and friends in from out of town during our wedding. I stayed in a corner suite the night before my wedding, and it was so nice to have the extra room to get ready before the wedding. There was a large bathroom with shower, tub and dual sinks with a large lighted vanity, and a separate room with the potty and another sink. All of those different areas came in handy while getting ready! There was also a large sitting room with big windows, a couch, and several chairs. We were able to comfortably have three people getting ready in there (with three different hair/makeup people) and it was never cramped. We also stayed the night of our wedding, and we loved it. We ordered room service (since we really didn't get to eat at our wedding) and it was so good. Again, the extra room came in handy as we had a place to put my dress, K's suit, flowers, cake, room service trays and more, and were able to relax in our room without all that clutter. The room service was great, and the morning coffee service was a big plus. Every single person we encountered was so helpful, polished and professional, we were all very impressed. Having Flint as part of this hotel makes a huge difference (in my opinion) in the quality of the food and drinks. We had a few tiny problems with the valets finding our cars quickly, but I think that's because we had multiple people under the same last name in the hotel. It was not a big enough deal that it even mattered, but there could be some room for improvement there.  All in, I couldn't have imagined staying anywhere else the night before my wedding, or getting ready anywhere else. And even if you only stay one night, you really should stay there the night of your wedding if you can. It's worth a little bit of money to pamper yourselves on the night of your big day!The hotel truly is "as good as it gets." The Colcord is a truly beautiful hotel with a little of that early 1900s swagger. The Missus and I stayed here for Valentine's Day and were completely blown away with how everything just seemed perfect.The room was clean and furnished with a big screen tv, nice furniture, and the most comfortable bed I've ever laid on. The bathroom was spotless, as well. Overall, everything in our room either looked new or was new. It really was impressive. \The hotel staff were extremely friendly and helpful. I'm not the type of guy that enjoys having a door held open for him and at Colcord...they open EVERY door except your room door for you. Kinda made me feel important. They have room service, but I was content with just walking down to the Flint, grabbing a bottle of bubbly, and retreating back to the room. Overall, I was extremely impressed with the Colcord. It's easily the coolest, prettiest, and most comfortable hotel I've ever stayed at.Did you know Colcord is actually spelled F-A-B-U-L-O-U-S? This gorgeous downtown property full of swank and swagger has every little detail covered. Seriously - from the onsite restaurant (Flint - which serves food later than most OKC restaurants!) to the richly-appointed rooms which beg you to stay, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this hotel to even the most finicky of friends.The bed is made up so lovely that it almost hurt to pull the covers back... and, I specifically carved out 30 minutes of time upon arrival just to luxuriate under the covers before we needed to get moving. Plush perfection.Service was on-point - my one recommendation is to allow plenty of time to retrieve your car from valet as it took anywhere from 5-15 minutes.Don't pass on this one just because you think it may be out of your budget - if the timing is right, you can get in for well under $200/night.I don't hand these things out lightly: it takes a lot for a pricey hotel to get 5* from me.  Though not perfect, Colcord earns it.  Stayed 3 nights for business, first week in June.  Shopped rates and found this hotel fairly-priced, comparable to the Sheraton (stayed there, blah).  Easy choice.  We needed proximity to the business district, particularly the courthouse.  This spot is in the shadows of the Devon tower (check out the patio terrace!).  Check in on Sunday afternoon was seamless. Our two rooms were ready, beside one another on the same floor.  Ate daily at the Flint restaurant, once for dinner, a couple times utilizing the patio for drinks and post-day recap of the trial.  Restaurant was very good for breakfast, and okay for dinner.  It's pricey.Experienced a couple mis-steps:  a) "coffee wake up" was only delivered as scheduled 1/3 mornings.  First morning--ommitted; second-got the desk wake up call, no coffee; third- coffee arrived as expected.b) Upon reviewing my folio had (1) a double charge (same amount for one drink) on the bill from Flint patio bar, and (2) one extra day's parking for one of vehicles (wife brought car on the last day).  Both were quickly corrected over email with the hotel after i returned home.But the pros so greatly outweigh the cons--a) room comfort, great bed, spacious room, great TVs--ACTUALLY HAVE HD, unlike so many in the midwest); b) impressive lobby & historic nature of the building; c) restaurant is well-accoutred with bfast, lunch, dinner, drinks menu; love the multipurpose nature of the space--separate patio bar so you can come chill in flip flops; d) location (convention center/ CHK area/ business district/ park across from Devon) is top notch;e) service was generally good and friendly; loved the car service to drop us and our huge loads of stuff at the courthouse;f) though it's not cheap to stay here, they do NOT nickle and dime the customer: WiFi, morning coffee, bottled water replaced daily, etc.  Such are the elements of a 5* mid-western hotel.  My fave in OKC, by a mile.
review_content_20: Stayed here for two nights. Awesome boutique hotel. Everything was tastefully redone and it had a great location. The area around it is kind of dead but Bricktown is a 10 minute walk away. Internet speed was very fast which is always a plus. Restaurant in the hotel is very average (for dinner at least)  and pricey. The yogurt parfait here in the morning is awesome though. Highly recommend this place.What a gorgeous hotel located in Downtown OKC....I was very impressed with the decor, overall service, and room accommodations at the Colcord during my 2 night stay. My room was super sized and include 2 sitting areas that included a chaise lounge and also two elegant wingback chairs flanked by a pedestal table. The bathroom vanity was expansive with well-lit lighting and a deep closet area too. I was impressed by the Bvlgari toiletries as well - NICE TOUCH!The bed was very comfortable and I also appreciated the touch-key "Do Not Disturb" option near the door.Upscale yet comfy restaurant and lounge Flint was on the ground floor and offered up some stiff cocktails and tasty late night bites to tide me over during a particularly fun night.My only annoyances were that my key card had to keep getting reset (3x during my stay) and there was an occasion where we waited for an excessive bit of time for a valet to assist us when we returned one evening. Overall, this is a fabulous option in OKC and I hope to stay here again!TIP: Fantastic coffee and tea service to your room!Beautiful hotel and friendly staff.  Big room, nice bathroom, comfy beds, and quiet room.  Short walk to Bricktown and it is right next to the Botanical Gardens.  Dog friendly hotel.  Only thing that was questionable to me was that they allow dogs in the hotel rooms (for a fee), but won't allow dogs on their restaurant's patio.  However, would definitely stay again.We stayed here during a weekend trip to OKC. It's in a great location for walking to Bricktown and the Oklahoma City memorial and museum. The hotel was very clean and contemporary with a very nice looking restaurant (Flint) downstairs. We didn't have time to try the restaurant but it was very busy on a fri night.  Our room was very spacious and had L'Occitane soaps and shampoos. The only complaint I have about this hotel is the shower. First of all, there was no door separating the shower area from the rest of the room. It was odd. It was behind a wall, so the person watching tv in bed could not see the shower, but still, you definitely don't want to share this room with someone you're not super comfortable with, because there is almost no privacy. Also, the shower had no door to it. It was a European type shower, so water came out of it and the floor got wet. However all in all this was a wonderful upscale hotel and I would definitely return!Loved my stay here - it was clean and really charming inside. The bed was SO comfy and I love having GIANT towels! It was nice to have a big enough room to spread out and do work when needed, but also relax on a surface other than your bed. One other treat was wake-up call coffee. What a nice way to wake up! Much better than a loud phone ringing. :)Check-in was easy and I used the free downtown shuttle service both nights to get around for dinner. Looking forward to staying here next time I'm in OKC.I was lucky enough to win a free night stay here and decided to use it for Valentine's Day. We had the most wonderful experience. We stayed in a king suite and it was so nice! The bed was amazingly comfortable. There are a large amount of tv channels along with free wifi. We had some miscommunication with the service but they took care of everything so I was pleased with that. You can get room service provided by Flint which is on their first floor, but you can also just go down there to order and save a few bucks since the room service is more expensive. This is a beautiful, historic hotel that I am proud to have in OKC.The lobby itself is worth a touristy walk-through from Devon Energy Center if you're an architecture fanatic. The staff are quite friendly towards randos wandering through their structural wonderland in awe. This combination of strategic wood paneling, wrought iron stairways, and monochromatic marble would arouse most people's aesthetics.While on business in OK City, stayed at the Colcord.  Great experience...a very nice hotel.  I recommend.  I stayed in a suite with very nice views of the city. Suite was large with a living room, a bed room, a hot tub and a shower as well as two large Hi Def televisions, and very comfortable bed.  The staff was very accommodating and friendly. A little pricey but worth it, and the connected restaurant (Flint) is quite good, and the hotel appears to be recently renovated.Liked it at first.  Rooms smell of moisture and latent smoke.  All the renovation in the world  haven't made this place better.  Staff is great, accommodating, and is honest in trying to deal with the problems you call them about, but the management can't whistle the big issues the hotel has away.  There are humidifiers or something in all the rooms I've been in. They're loud and I don't know what they are supposed to be doing.  If you have an envelope it will be stuck together in the morning. Much better choices aroundI've stayed in many fine hotels  but I have never seen such OUTSTANDING service as in the Colcord.  Everyone was friendly, interested in helping IMMEDIATELY and went out of their way to  make our conference and my stay over the top!  The hotel is beautiful.  I've stayed in two different rooms during stays at the Colcord and I give both the highest recommendation.  The combination between a historic hotel with all of the most modern amenities and expected in a luxury hotel was fabulous.  The beds were extremely comfortable.  Room service was fast and the food was very good.  Oklahoma people are very nice and the people in the hotel are very nice people. Thanks for treating me royally.   I highly recommend.This hotel is fabulous!  It's located in the mecca of Downtown OKC, next to the Myriad Botanical Gardens.   The hotel is still under some construction, but I hardly noticed it unless I was outside. We were in town for a wedding and I truly have to say this hotel is close to perfection.  The staff is great, the rooms were beautiful and clean, the original art deco structure is still very present, I love that they kept the original design. The rooms come equipped with air purifiers, huge plasma TV, swanky bathrooms and the most comfortable bed I think I have ever slept on. It's the type of room that if you are only staying one night, you wish you were staying longer.  I was somewhat upset when we had to checkout...hmph.The room was so quiet I never heard ANYONE other than me and MP.  The shower was nice but weird.  No door.  I'm old fashioned (I guess), I make a big ol'mess when I shower.  So the whole time I was bathing I was trying to not flood the place, did a pretty good job.  Shower was still super refreshing.  The complimentary toiletries are Bvlgari and very lovely, hair dryer, iron and safe are also present in your room.  The hotel also has a concierge lounge that is open till midnight on the weekends!  This means, that after a night out you can come back to the hotel and drink and have a little nosh before bedtime.  Sounds good to me! Also, I seriously can't pay them enough compliments.  The staff is truly so amazing.  Everyone from the front desk to the guys valeting your cars (which I would recommend, $10 a night).  I'm super picky about hotels, I'm like that crazy lady who inspects EVERYTHING in a  room.  Thank you 60 Minutes for the expose a few years back...ugh.  Anyhooo, I think its a fantastic hotel, next time I'm in OKC, we will def be staying here....If you can get around the street construction and repair on Robinson street in downtown OKC, then you should stay at the Colcord. This boutique hotel is very charming and is priced comparably to the Sheraton and other chain hotels that are in the area. The staff was warm and welcoming from the  three valets who met our car, opened our doors, carried our luggage and escorted us to the front desk; to the front desk personnel who were polite and efficient. Apparently the Colcord was built in 1906 and renovated into a boutique hotel 10 or 15    years ago, and it is very lovely. It sure beats a cookie cutter experience at a chain.  You can tell it was an office building back in the 20th century, but that is part of the charm.  From the elevator banks in the lobby with the metal / Art Deco look, to the marbled dual staircase, you can't help but feel pampered even before you get to your room.  The rooms are expansive, and laid out in a "U" shape; (at least ours was). After you slid your magnetic key card in the door (I half expected to use a skeleton key!), you walk down a narrow entry to reveal the large suite replete with a 60' LG high def TV (that even  offered the OKC TV sub-channels).  The king-sized bed was adorned with soft linens and numerous pillows. I wish I were adroit enough to tell you that it was "Egyptian cotton" or such-and-such thread count; but suffice it to say that it was high end bedding - very comfortable!There was no tub in the bath, but the shower was strong and hot (let me take a moment to thank mngt for not putting lo-flow shower heads in the bathroom).The other thing that struck me is that when I first turned on the hot water in the lav, it was  hot immediately; no waiting for the water to "warm up"The only blemish on a great hotel stay is that the windows were very dirty. While we kept the blinds/curtains drawn for most of the time, when we checked in around 4pm we went to look out the eastern facing windows to reveal a caked layer of dirt and dust. It may be time for management to pay for window cleaners.  Lastly (and only b/c I am nitpicking); the walls were a little bare and could use a floor length mirror and maybe a picture or two plus there was a finial missing on the floor lamp in the room. I only noticed because I bumped into the lamp and knocked the shade off!)Okay, I know u was long-winded in this review, but I whole-heartedly recommend this hotel. It is literally across the street from OKC Thunder games and in the middle of everything.  We also had room service from the in house restaurant "Flint"; look for my review of FLINT in the restaurant section of Yelp.One word: DNR!I stayed here the night before I got married across the street at the Myriad Gardens and for my honeymoon. The staff was exceedingly friendly and the service was superb. The rooms were very nice as well. I enjoyed having complimentary coffee delivered to my room in the morning. The only two things that keep this place from getting a five star review are the fact that they key cards tend to get their information demagnetized rather quickly and the strange set up of a glass pane on the showers instead of a shower curtain. My brother and I enjoyed the room that we split the night before and my wife and I enjoyed the suite on our wedding night. If you want a great hotel to stay in OKC I'd recommend this one (I'd imagine that it would be a great place to stay at after a Thunder game as well.)I've stayed here three years in a row for an event and it's only gotten better. The service this time around has been wonderful.Jacque (spelling??) at the Flint bar/restaurant was awesome and super friendly. I look forward to next year.Beautiful hotel on the outside and inside. Walking distance to shops, museums, and restaurants. I suggest not ordering room service or paying 25.00 for valet. Each time we ordered room service, they forgot at least 2 things, which is annoying.....by time you get back up with what you forgot, my food is cold. We chose this hotel so that we could have less hassles being unfamiliar with ok city. The valet is always late, they do not leave your car tuning for you or open the doors. The Flint restaurant manager did personally come to our room and apologize, and removed room service charges. That was nice, but still not what I expect from such a top notch hotel. We decided to go directly to Flint restaurant and order breakfast since we are starving. We shall see how this service goes.We stayed at the Colcord Hotel for a girlfriends weekend while we attended the Peace, Love and Goodwill Festival at the Myriad Botanical Gardens (which were seriously right next door).  The hotel is just lovely, the room was comfortable and clean - I wouldn't say opulent, but it was everything you need.  Big beds, lots of pillows, L'Occitane products (teeny tiny ones, but nice) in the bath.  Showers only, no tubs.  We were on the 10th floor and had a great view of the gardens from our window.  Cocktails outdoors from the restaurant was a highlight of our stay.  The breakfast menu looked tasty and was reasonable, but we choose to venture elsewhere.  TV reception was spotty, but that's about the worst thing I can say.  There was a humidifier in our room (I've read other reviews and now see why) but room 1006 is not musty at all.  Oh, and several guests had their pets with them!  We were surprised it was dog friendly.  Too bad most the guests aren't as nice as the staff!  LOL.  I would love to stay there again...Wanted it to be great- it wasn't. Valet and bell service were topnotch. Front Desk was uninterested. Room was great except for musky smell- humidifier was running. Bed was good- nice linens, etc. Nice bathroom.PROS:Really nice looking hotel. Friendly front desk staff. Stylish suites, and well-done remodeling.CONS:Cheap bouncy mattresses (you can feel the mattress springs poking your back). Horribly rude and unhelpful valet staff. Non-existent bellhops. No free parking anywhere. The hotel will charge you extra money for a "parking pass" that you can just buy at the garage for cheaper. There is a restaurant inside the hotel that tries to be gourmet, but doesn't execute. Rude service and lots of mess-ups at the restaurant. Extra charges on our room bill for services we never used, although the front desk staff gladly removed the charges after bringing them to their attention.All in all, the hotel looks really nice, but for the price, the service is a D-minus.Excellent hotel! I will stay here again. Super comfy bed, complimentary coffee with wakeup each morning, bottled water, luxury car shuttle to Bricktown with very knowledgable, courteous drivers, efficient service at check-in, lux toiletries, huge room, giant tv, free wifi, everything sparkling clean, great view, perfect room temp, dramatic lobby.Problems (resulting in 4 stars): one of the water sprinklers for fire suppression in our ceiling was missing the chrome cover so it was a spigot sticking out of a large hole in the ceiling--very unsightly and ruins the mood. Also, the stopper in the sink did not work so I could not have hot water in the sink to shave with. Irritating! Small details but important in a luxury hotel. It's all about attention to detail. Oh, and the man who helped with our luggage when we left was very nice but he absolutely stank of cigarette smoke. He should change clothes occasionally.Ordered breakfast room service. Delicious pancakes! But our bacon was burned! No excuse for burned bacon. The fresh OJ was delicious.Highly recommend.
review_content_40: This is a beautiful hotel - very clean and well-kept.  The rooms have an apartment like feel and the windows give great views of the Botanical Gardens across the street!  The beds were comfortable with a warm and comfy comforter.  The television is a nice addition at close to 47" with many free digital cable stations.  The hotel staff is extremely friendly, welcoming, and helpful, especially Sheneca and Cleo!There is some issue with the maid staff replacing shampoo, conditioner, lotion, and soap as well as vaccuuming.  We've been here since Monday, October 15th, and I had to ask for more shampoo, conditioner, lotion, and soap.There are some very nice amenities, like free bottled water, apples, and newspapers daily.  The best thing...FREE WIFI!This hotel was obviously designed by a man. Allow me to explain.They advertise "European-style showers" as a perk. This is not a perk; it means there isn't a bathtub for awesome hotel bubble baths. Sad. The toiletries, while fancy and by Bvlgari, smell strongly and also of man. Not something your average female will slather on her body fellas, sorry. Additionally, the flower pictures in the hallway, while appearing to be very feminine at first glance, are VERY FEMININE at second glance, ifyouknowwhatImean. Ahem.All that aside, I really enjoyed my stay here. There's quite a bit of construction on the streets surrounding the hotel, as well as in the attached restaurant but my room on the 9th floor was an oasis of calm. The staff certainly goes out of their way to ensure an enjoyable stay. I experienced a couple small issues that were resolved expediently and with a smile. They've made up for the lack of a restaurant by providing a complimentary hot breakfast and hors d'oeuvres at dinner time. I didn't take advantage of either, but nice touch!Also, best bed ever. You can even order one; they're that good.Corporate Meetings / Workshops / Events THIS IS YOUR PLACE!!!! The company I work for hosts 12 workshops a year for C-Suite Execs and we needed a venue that our out of state clients would be pleased with to stay at and a venue that was cool but still functional to meet in as well. The Colcord has accommodated us to no end. They even came up with a unique out of the box floor plan layout for us when we gave them our vision and then they produced. We wanted a non stuffy feel for our workshop full of business execs, and they delivered. Rebecca Eaton is YOUR GIRL to work with for events. She is amazing, has the best attitude, and attention to detail. She is genuine in her work ethic and so easy to work with. She has THE BEST customer service skills, and a friendly demeanor about her too. The event staff is amazing too, every single one of them. Frank, BJ, Richard, etc. ALL of our C-Suite client have been very happy with their stay at the Colcord, their rooms, the atmosphere, and especially their experiences at Flint, the restaurant downstairs in the lobby area of the hotel. The Terrace Room is where we have our workshops / meeting/ corporate events. They've set up the room in a very USEFUL, COZY, FUN, LASTING IMPRESSION, unconventional way. They know how to think outside of the box and provide EXCELLENT service.Very nice, full service hotel, which was quite welcome after several days on the road.  Room was large and comfortable; staf was friendly and efficient.This hotel was a mere ten dollars more than the Sheraton, which is across the street, but it is a world of difference!I first discovered the Colcord when walking by. We'd checked in to the Sheraton, and hadn't realized it was unsuitable. While walking by the Colcord, I asked the doorman where I could buy some bottled water. He went inside and gave me a complimentary bottle.An hour or so later, we'd vacated the Sheraton and had checked in to the Colcord. It was a *very* busy time, with a VIP actor and sports stars in attendance for a charity weekend of events, along with many NBA players in for the basketball series with the Thunder, but you would have never known it from the friendly efficiency of the staff.The staff was unfailingly wonderful, from the front desk, to the doormen, everyone in the restaurant, and housekeeping. Our room, a King, was incredible, with a shower that had to be 5X7 and glass walled.The hotel goes the extra mile, with the complimentary water, the gourmet coffee and tea by the cup in the lobby.Internet service was speedy and we were able to connect without any problems. The servers, managers, and cooks in the restaurant (especially Jordan and the woman from Tinker who works on the weekends) were phenomenal. Make sure to try the Jerk Pork Chops--amazing! Wines were suggested that really brought out the flavor of the meat.Breakfast was similarly good (the lobster crepes are amazing!). The wait staff were attentive without being pushy and were incredibly friendly.This hotel has a storied history and it is obvious in the variety of touches that harken back to a time when it was one of the tallest buildings in OKC. It has such warm and unique charm and the staff embodies that feel.Only a short walk to Bricktown, the memorial,  and the area, and a short drive to shopping, this hotel is convenient to it all!I'll definitely be back!We got a great deal and really enjoyed it. The rooms are generously sized with charm. Art deco design for an old bank building. Nice shower and bath area (although the room had a shower door and not a curtain which got the floor all wet). They bring you complementary coffee or tea in the morning which was a great way to start the day. I would definitely come back.My husband and I visited Oklahoma City July 18th-July 20th for a concert. We decided to stay at the Colcord because we could walk everywhere we wanted to visit; we had read that the parking situation downtown is terrible as you have to valet or park in the large parking structure. The hotel is beautiful, inside and out. Built in 1910, the Colcord was the first "skyscraper" in Oklahoma City. The detail on the outside of the building and inside the lobby area is gorgeous. The room we got, just a standard suite was beautiful. The bed, the chaise lounge, and the seating area was all comfortable. The shower was very nice and all the amenities within the room were appropriate. We were surprised to find out that there was no refrigerator, because we typically bring our own drinks, but it wasn't too much of a bother. Our toilet had some type of problem during our stay in which it wouldn't flush on command. You would pull the handle and it would do nothing, for about 20 minutes, then it would randomly flush. We called it in and it was fixed immediately During our stay, the heat was in the triple digits every day. The lack of a pool at the hotel was very much noticed. To ease some of the walking in the heat, we did opt to use the free hotel shuttle to go to dinner one night. A gentleman in a nice private Cadillac took us to, then picked us up, from the Melting Pot. Unfortunately, the beauty of the hotel is marred by the ridiculous amount of construction taking place all around it. Next to the Colcord there is a monster skyscraper being built which has prevented easily driving through to the Colcord. Also, the street running on the other side of the Colcord was getting work done so there was traffic cones everywhere and people directing traffic. Thank goodness we chose to walk everywhere. Let me just state that the construction did not present a problem with noise inside the rooms. It was peaceful and quiet!For those not aware, parking is not free, I believe it is 7 dollars a day at the structure next door and 10 dollars for valet at the hotel (this is what we chose).I am in OKC for a conference an the Colcord Hotel was one of the hotel choices...This is a great hotel.  It has all the charm of an old, historic hotel and has been very tastefully remodeled.  The lobby is very nice and the restaurant, La Baguette, is quite good and very reasonably priced for a hotel restaurant.The rooms are awesome.  I had a corner / king - sitting area, large bedroom and an enormous bathroom.  The shower is incredible.  My room had a great view of Bricktown.The hotel has a very spacious and well equipped fitness center, but has no pool.The staff is friendly and attentive.Now for the negatives...The hotel offers free WIFI, however, the signal is extremely weak and does not reach rooms that are furthest away from the router (i.e. elevator).  I talked with the front desk, they confirmed the problem and offered to move me to another room.  I decided to stay where I was.  Therefore, the free WIFI was of no use to me.Now for the big issue...  Devon Corporation is building their headquarters building next to the hotel.  Building a skyscraper is very, very noisy.  The construction starts early and continues late into the day.  As great as the hotel is, I may consider not staying here until the construction is complete.Even with the issues, I gave the hotel four (4) stars...My wife has wanted to stay at the Colcord for several years, but we had gotten into a habit of staying at another nice hotel downtown.  However, I decided to surprise her with a trip to the city and a stay at the Colcord.Upon arrival the staff was exceptionally professional and pleasant.  We were equally pleased with our room.  My wife loves to be pampered and to feel spoiled when she stays at a nice hotel and one of the first things she looks for is the nice, fluffy, and clean bath robes.  Guess what, they were there!  She was sold on the Colcord at this point.After settling into our room we decided to go down to the lounge and have a drink and a small appetizer prior to our evening on the town.  We were going to a tapas and wine tasting later in the evening and were not wanting much.  Being accustom to the other establishment we normally stay, we decided to both order an appetizer.  Wow!  The cheese plate came out on a cutting board with several different cheeses, meats and breads.  This would have been more than enough for the both of us.  Then my burger arrived shortly after.  Not sure why it was on the appetizer menu after seeing the size.  However, I was not disappointed with the real meat and great bun!The selection of drinks and beers was great and the bar staff was more than helpful with explanations of the different drinks that were offered.When we left for the evening, the door staff offered to give us a ride in the hotel's complimentary shuttle to our event.  We were within walking distance, but were impressed with the offer and that their shuttle is not a van, but a Cadillac Escalade.After a restful night's sleep, the staff delivered freshly brewed coffee to our door with our wakeup call "knock". We then went back to the Flint restaurant for breakfast.  This is when we met Victoria, our waitress.  She resounded the other pleasant experiences we had at the Colcord. She was very professional, cheery, and pleasant.  She made suggestions for our meal and we were very pleased with the food she had suggested.Thanks to the hotel staff and all around pleasant experience we had at the Colcord.  We will be loyal repeating guests.Thank you to you the staff!Lots of potential but just misses the mark.  It's a historical hotel that has recently been renovated.  We were in town from Austin for a rowing regatta and wanted to stay somewhere nice.   When you walk in the hotel is playing dance/club music- kind of loud. It doesn't match.  I like dance/club music in its appropriate venue- a historical hotel is not that venue UNLESS you are in Miami on the beach in an art deco hotel with doors open on both ends and sheers of fabric flowing throughout the entire bottom floor of the hotel..... The rooms were okay.  Comfy beds, which is what you want in a hotel.  They just lack attention to detail- needed more towels and Kleenex and they missed it- even when I purposely left the empty Kleenex box on top of the holder in plain site.  The bed was thrown back together, not actually remade.  the place was moldy. The front desk staff were not warm and fuzzy at all.  They always seemed slightly frantic and running around, even when no one else was up there.  Just not smooth and enjoyable. Don't get me started on the restaurant, Flint. Just read my separate review for them. Overall not impressed and will not return. Bummer.What a great hotel!!  We spent the night in an end room with a king sized bed. The room is considered a suite. There was a comfortable sofa and chair. The hotel provided complimentary bottled water, delicious Illig coffee, and high end designer toiletries. The bed was awesome.  All the staff was very welcoming and helpful. The hotel is at a great location tooI absolutely loved my experience at the Colcord. Our suite was huge; a living room, a bed room, a hot tub and a shower as well as two Hi Def televisions. The staff was very accommodating and friendly. A little pricey but well worth it.Stayed here Sun-Tuesday. Great hotel. Great service with a smile and friendly staff.  Free shuttle and mins from Bricktown!!Loved this hotel. Great boutique hotel w/ reasonable rates, friendly and attentive service and nice decor. We travel with our dogs a lot and always find places that are relatively hassle free for pets (no 40lb weight limit or nonrefundable deposits) so I was glad I called a few that I turned down because it eventually led me to the Colcord. Our room was big and super clean with a sitting area w/ 2 chairs and lamp/table, an entryway so the door didn't open and expose the room/bed, lots of drawers and closet space, comfy bed, small pillows but amazingly they worked out okay, complimentary bottled water, big windows, big bathrooms, robes, flat screen TV etc etc. Check out their web site for pictures, the hotel is on the Historic Register and they did an excellent job w/ the renovation and decoration. We didn't have time to try the restaurant or room service but the menu looked nice and the prices seemed good too. The location is right downtown and across the street from a little botanical garden if you need to get out and take a walk. No more chain hotels in OKC for us now that I've found this place!We stayed here while in town for a rock show.  The Colcord looked like the best place to stay that was near the ford center so that is what we chose.  Overall it was a good choice.  The room was upscale and modern. Staff was nice and the room was very comfortable. Only slight down side was the wifi sucked (since i was here for pleasure and not business it was not that bad since we rarely used it).  Other issue was the construction going on next door.  The hotel cant really help that so i did not really factor it in on my rating. I would stay here again for fun.This review is of two rooms: a 5th floor "corner king" and a 4th floor suite.I stayed here with my two cats while our house was being deep cleaned. In accordance with downtown laws, there are specific rooms designated for pets; none of them are higher than the 5th floor. The view, however, from the 5th floor is still very nice! Ask to be on the botanical garden side--its view is like a mini central park--tall, lush green trees amongst concrete. The corner king had the best views and light--LOTS OF LIGHT!The rooms are decorated very nicely. If you like contemporary decor, you'll feel at home at the Colcord. It has beautiful appointments typical of nicer modern homes. The mattress and bedding were nice, too. The bathrooms are large and lovely. The corner king had a garden tub/shower combo and the suite had a jetted garden tub and separate glass shower that had great tile. The shower head wasn't so great, but it was powerful. The towels were of typical hotel quality, but in the suite you do get bath sheets.The toiletries were low quality. The robes looked quite cheap with thin royal blue velour shells and terry lining. The terry was pilled. It looked like someone's ratty old robe--not something you want to step into after a bath.There was some dust on the TV (they are approximately 32" flat panel in the corner king, and a 32" & 42" in the suite). There was a reeses peanut butter cup under the sofa--which luckily I found before my cats. Windows were very dirty. The remote for the TV in the corner king didn't work. The remote for the TV in the suite worked, but only at very short range.The corner king was $200/night and the suite was $300/night on a non-event weekend (Friday & Saturday). It was a little pricey, but is it worth it overall? Yes & no. If it's more important that things be aesthetically-pleasing--then yes. If it's more important that things be practical--then no. It is undeniably gorgeous (I want their designer), but you don't really get much for what you pay. There isn't much luxury in the the "luxury boutique" except visually.If you're staying with a cat who likes to hide under the bed, get the suite. You can put him in the living area and he won't have anything to hide under that you can't easily move to get him. We had to have the manager come and lift the enormous king bed (we could have lifted it but didn't want to be liable for damage) to get our cat because he crawled up IN the base!
