I feel this was an oversight on their part because it was a pet room, but I don't want to nitpick. I would stay in the suite (with cats) and in the corner king (without cats) again. If you care about the tub, make sure you ask which is in the room because not all of them are the same.Best in okc. Trust the great reviews... This place is truly a gem. Impeccable service, luxurious accommodations, and overall wonderful hotel.  Free shuttle to/from Bricktown?!  Just another reason why this is the hotel of choice for a great downtown OKC adventure!The staff at the Colcord Hotel are so friendly and helpful.  This is the best staff at any hotel I have been at this year.  The complimentary coffee delivery each morning is lovely!We stayed at the Colcord Hotel last year as a treat and what a treat it was! We loved it and it was definately the nicest hotel we've stayed in. The sheets and towels were so luxurious and the bathroom was huge. The decor was simple, but beautiful. It's centrally located downtown and close to Bricktown. We are going again this year in May. We would highly recommend this hotel.I'm actually writing this review while staying at the hotel on business. I usually stay at the Hilton Garden Inn but have decided to upgrade my stay while staying in OKC. The Hotel Colcord is a very nice hotel and I have to say I was pleasantly surprised with the quality of the rooms. When I showed up at the hotel I asked for an upgraded room and they did so without any hesitation or increase in price. I received a deluxe king corner suite. This room is huge ( 646 sq ft.) and has a couch and chair. The accommodations are contemporary and tasteful. The AC works awesome! The bathroom is very stylish and includes a standup shower with Kohler fixtures. The only drawback is the fitness center doesn't have weights over 25 pounds and doesn't have a great selection of workout equipment. Also, this hotel does not have a pool. Other than that, it's a great hotel and I will continue to stay here when I come to OKC.

review_content: If you're looking for a solid, economical stay with friendly, smiling faces greeting you as you check in; then head to the Biltmore in Oklahoma City. I knew I made the right decision as soon as I got out of the car. That's because when I did get out of the car; there were two ladies who worked there, and they were singing "This little light of mine..I'm gonna let it shine" as they watched the incoming thunderstorm that evening. Their smiling faces and friendly manner was the perfect way to end my 8-hour drive from Albuquerque. When you walk into their lobby, you get the feel of 1950's Oklahoma. It's a huge lobby with a rock wall, and fireplace (which wasn't lit, but they told me it is during winter). The ladies walked me in and were fun to talk to as they handled my reservation flawlessly. The only "hit" I'll give this hotel concerns a funny, (but not overpowering) smell that was in my room. It wasn't enough of a smell to make me change rooms; and I quickly acclimated to the scent. It really wasn't that big of a deal. The king size bed was extremely comfortable; and I honestly didn't want to get up from it after I plopped myself down on it right after I dropped my bags on the floor. The room was decorated with kind of outdated, but not tacky 1970's decor. I ran that A/C like a horse, and it kept the room frosty cold, as I like it whenever I stay in hotels during the summer. The bathroom was clean, and the hot water plentiful as I washed off the dust from the 8-hour drive that had just ended.I met a good friend at the hotel, and we hung in one of the two bars in the hotel. The Bombay Room was full of (smoking) patrons who were laughing and talking with the young lady tending bar. At $4 a beer, it was a cool place to hang out during the rainy evening. There's an indoor pool right next to the Bombay Room, as well as at least one outdoor pool. Since it was raining, I didn't make use of either, but I did notice that both were kept up well. Supposedly, there's a country/western bar in the place as well; but few things interest me less than hearing ol' Toothless Jim singing about his damned dog and truck for hours on end; so I passed on hanging there.I had a great experience there, and I only spent about $60 after fees and taxes and all that crap. Along with the great service was the convenience of the location. It's right off the I-40 with easy "on/off" access. If you're on a budget, and need to stop in Oklahoma City, then you really can't do much better than the Biltmore. If I'm ever in this town again on a budget; then I'll make sure to book a room right here.I wish i could give them no stars. This is what we dealt with... The ceiling caved in. On the bathroomWorst hotel I have ever stayed at! I had to get 4 different sets of keys and had to have maintenance come fix the lock. Not only did it take maintenance 45mins to get to my room to fix it... They just walked right in without knocking. I pulled the blankets back and there were stains on the sheets... A LOT of stains. Rooms are very outdated. I had a room booked for 3 days and I ended up canceling before the 1st night was over. I refused to shower there because I was so grossed out by the place.The worst hotel I have ever stayed at in my humble life. The feel of the hotel is great, maybe someone had a lot of funding money in the 1980s, it is cowboy and horse themed. And everything they have as decoration appears to be the same things they had in the 80s. That being said, I would not avoid a hotel because of dusty horse statues. BUT, I will avoid this hotel at all cost after my last experience. I went into my room and turned the lights on and there were about 15!! roaches that scattered, as we looked closer they were actually everywhere, but blended in with the carpets ect. The contrast between their red shells and the off-white/yellow bathroom tile created an intense opportunity to correctly identify them. I got the chills, afraid that I was stepping on them as I set my luggage on my 80's bed spread. I called the front desk, they apologized and offered no refund, only to move us to the "best room" they had. We gathered all our luggage, left room 217 (home to many lifeforms) , and went to our new room '103'. When I went inside I turned on the lights, half-expecting to see more things scatter. I did not see any bugs but as it turned out, their best room was no different. In fact, it was missing a few amenities the previous room had had. For example, the curtain did not even cover the window, which faced into a courtyard and pool, absolutely no privacy, the TV was now down graded into the really large ones we used to use in 90s, and the bed-spread had cigarette holes and stains everywhere, so much that I took it off and slept on a towel. I had to leave for the airport at 4:45 am and at this time I gave up I was too tired.THEN to ice the cake, when I was checking out and waiting on the shuttle at about 4:30am, I requested an out-going mail need and the worker spoke english just enough to laugh and tell me "WE DONT DO THAT HERE". I asked, "What do you mean, this is a hotel, of course you mail things." He REFUSED for five minutes, enough for the security/shuttle driver to come up and ask what was wrong, I explained it to him and he also said WE DONT DO THAT HERE. I wanted to cry I was so flabbergasted that I paid over $50.00 for the most roach-infested, invasive room I have seen, minus TV shows like COPS, AND they refused to offer any services like out-going mail. NO EXPECTATIONS WERE MET EVEN THOUGH THEY ADVERTISE FULL SERVICE. I will be contacted the BBB over them. I hope all the other people and their concerns, whom the hotel seems to ignore, will also stand up for themselves and insist on retribution.BED BUGS!!!!!!We stayed at the Biltmore 1.5 nights. We only made it half way through the second night because my wife found bed bugs in the bathroom and under the bed. I immediately brought the bed bug to the front desk and received a refund for our entire stay. Before speaking with the front desk employees I had to wait in a line for about 20 minutes while other guests lobbied their complaints about issues unrelated to bed bugs.We were staying with our 1 year old, which meant waking him up in the middle of the night so we could travel to another hotel.Aside from the bed bugs the overall experience wasn't much better. Basically the hotel is trapped in the late 80's. It was probably once a nice place, but today's version is dirty and a bit unsavory. I guess the worst part of our experience was that the staff acted like this was just another day and the issue was nothing new to them.Fun place, TERRIBLE service. Been here multiple times, great atmosphere, rude staff. Seems to me that management is non-existent.By far the worst hotel and staff, just overall experience being here. I wouldn't suggest this place to a rotting corpse. So I made a reservation here for 4 nights. When I showed up it took at LEAST and hour to get me through. When I get to the room there isn't a fridge like advertised, when I called to the front desk to ask about it the woman beat around the bush. I asked her if there's any chance to to check on the eta. of the fridge to then she got a little defensive and laughed at me then assured me that she couldn't do that.No stars for this place. We had our family reunion here and the service was horrible. The employees were rude!! The AC did not work and it was 90 degrees outside. The food was disgusting as well. We have had several other reunions here but never again!!Very accommodating place. When I walked in the front desk was very helpful and pleasant. I got my room key no problems. I walk into the building I was to room in and the night security guard introduced himself and showed me to my room. My key wasn't program correctly and the security guard was MORE THAN HELPFUL in getting it activated. My room was right next to the pool area (only complaint was the noise). Early day next day so sleep is a MUST. I went back down to the front desk and asked if I could get another room. With no hesitation they made this request possible. No fuss no excuses he checked for an available room and WAAAA LAAA! Less than three minutes. This place is great! Very affordable and clean. Thank you guys for helping me get a great nights rest!I wish I could give this less stars. One of the worst hotel experiences I have ever had. Only desirable if you want a nice evening of meth addicts and men harassing you. -Dried blood all over the bathroom-police there for several hours-issue with with toilet and displaced for several hours-offered new room finally at midnight-dirty room smelling of stale smoke We are two young women traveling and everything about this hotel was unsafe. If I had children I would have immediately left. This hotel should have some sort of security. We ended leaving around midnight and had to find a new hotel. We felt bad for the two very friendly front desk clerks who were being screamed at by a unhappy guest every time we passed.Good value for the $49.99 per night that I am paying. I love the character of the hotel since it is "retro" itself, but the amenities in rooms are completely decent. Not luxurious, but I have lived in worse dorms.Some pros and cons to consider:- They make you sign an agreement saying you won't smoke in the rooms--the first non-smoking room they tried to put me in totally had chain smokers before me, but when I mentioned it they moved me though acted like it was difficult (there's plenty of vacancies they are advertising now so I don't see the issue!). Have seen many people with out-facing doors smoking in the doorway to their room... Depending on their knowledge of aerodynamics I suppose it's possible for the room to not stink later... But as a former smoker who doesn't want to be tempted the whole place sort of leaking the cigarette fumes of 40 years of abuse has bothered me.- Unlocked access doors from outside to the halls with rooms are all over the place. Convenient and discrete... but also alarming.- They allow pets, and the place isn't nice enough that I'll owe thousands for a pup's accident--big bonus. Be sure to discuss when you reserve or check in (as per their policy). They earned an extra star for the pet friendly status in my opinion. Also, excellent vets in the area so if something has happened it's a good base point to stay if you have an animal emergency or hospitalisation and you've driven in from far away.-Housekeeping very respectful of "do not disturb" signs so farRecommendations to bring:- Glade plug in Doo-hickey or whatever- That ozium odor spray that helps cigarette doors- Power strip with multiple outlets (all covertly hidden by furniture and one in my room didn't even have enough plugs for everything)- Possibly a door stop alarm but I bet it's ok not to,For the price of this hotel, I was very impressed. When we arrived, we had to wait in line for about 20 minutes, there were a lot of guests checking in. The woman who did our check in was very nice and helpful with explaining how to get to our room.The room was clean and fairly large. The amenities were older, but everything worked. I was particularly surprised by the age of the television, but it worked well.I noticed almost immediately that we didn't have a tv remote, and it was inconvenient that there was no refrigerator. I called guest services to request a remote. I was told that maintenance would come with one, but that never happened. We waited for maintenance for 2 hours, but we had dinner reservations, so we left. On our return, still no remote. I called again, and security came with a remote within 10 minutes.Checkout was fast, everyone was friendly.I would definitely recommend this hotel to my friends.prostitutes, dried blood sprayed on the wide of the mattress and box spring. a pool that is actually a dirt hole in the ground filled with discarded furniture. old dog turds piled up by entrances. carpet missing in huge chunks in the hallways. toilet not working, wifi not working, front desk not answering from hotel phone. initials scratched into the cabinet in the bathroom. and to top it off a racist receptionist who wouldnt let 2 mexican men stay there and then punished me by telling me i couldnt check in for 2 more hours (at 11pm). dont ever stay here EVERDo NOT stay here! The lobby reeks of smoke and my non smoking room wasn't much better! The hallway carpets are filthy with stains. The doors are hollow, noisy and beat up! Duct tape is used to hold the plumbing in place! The curtains don't close all the way! Need I go on? My flight was cx and this is where American Airlines put a few of us up for the night! Absolutely gross when there are so many other better hotels closer to the airport!Booked a two night stay and left after the first night. Should have known with the Hustlers Erotica store across the street that it may be a bit shady. The rooms are very outdated and old, don't let the website photos fool you. The hotel is a maze and hard to find things. After a 20 min. walk around we found an ice machine that worked; 3rd machine we tried. Beds are plywood hard. We could hear everything next door and would have rather not. We went to dinner and came back to find 3 police cars in the lot with lights on and walking through the hotel. Could not regulate the room temp. Was cold all night. This hotels allows pets so be ready to deal with barking dogs. The Chisholm Club charges $5 cover even if you are a guest and there was no band. The Bombay Club for casual cocktails was nothing but a drunkards bar. This was an upgrade to begin with. I would not recommend this hotel AT ALL!!!!Biltmore for fans of Western attire, and smoke on top of smoke with a layer of smoke wrapped in smoke with just a hint of smokey smoke.Biltmore for individuals who prefer that their surroundings not include trivial things like air conditioning.Biltmore to serve as a scene straight out of Breaking Bad when Jesse decides to go to that shady motel to get with the meth addict prostitute who had the grody teeth. Just to be clear, there are no prostitutes at this location (that I am aware of). Biltmore for patrons with low standards.Biltmore for people who expect less.Actually, Biltless may be more accurate.I'll stop now.P. S. The employees are delightful. Very kind, helpful people.P. P. S. John P. states that this place "ain't the Taj Mahal." I'm not sure if you know this John P., but the Taj Mahal is a mausoleum built by an emperor in memory of his (third) dead wife. A mausoleum is where you put (surprise, surprise) dead people. It is therefore quite different from a hotel. Not exactly an apples to apples comparison, is it? Just thought I'd toss that out there. Unless he was referring to the Trump Taj Mahal, then my response would be, "You're certainly right about that."I'm sitting on my bed at the biltmore as I type this. I've pushed one cricket out the door already, three more are lingering in the bathroom and since they're quiet (are they dead?) I'm fine with leaving them be. Another, however, seems to be hiding somewhere in the drapes and I'm debating on whether I'm willing to go through the hassle of requesting a new room, as this one seems to be infested with the critters. Will I wake up tomorrow with one on my face, cozying up with me on my bed? Am I willing to find out? Hmmm...Outside of the noisy roommates, the room smells. It's just dirty. I'm not uppity or coddled when it comes to hotels by any means, either. I grew up on Motel 6 and Best Western's. I still remember how i felt the first time I stayed with in a room with an INTERIOR facing door... All fancy and whatnot. Should have stuck with my roots. Passed plenty of the motel 6's to get here. Think the light's are still on?The term "you get what you pay for" comes to mind booked thru booking.com got a 5 day stay for $183. Not the best in the world. No flat screens people constantly lingering the place and worn outdated furniture. However the room was clean and neat. As for the staff this was why I left a 2 star rating. They seem like they are just waiting for their shift to be finished and customer service is the last thing on their mind. on check in I prepaid for the room and then they lost my booking email showing proof of payment ( I pulled up my copy of the receipt on my iPhone but they would not accept it and tried to make me pay twice). After a 45 minute call with booking.com they allowed me to check in. The free Breakfast buffet was excellent eggs bacon or sausage every morning this was a real pleasant surprise! If your looking for a cheap place to stay and don't care about the frills then the Biltmore is the place for you.I would rate no stars, but unable to. First off, do not stay here. It's a dump. The heater did not work in my room and the fridge was broke, so when I woke up in the morning I discovered my food was spoiled. I didn't check in until 11 p.m. I went straight to sleep. When I talked to management in the morning about how freezing it was and the fridge situation she just brushed it off and said you should have let us know. Oh, how was I supposed to do that when I went straight to sleep? Anyways, there are plenty of other motels in the area, so take my advice and do it moving. On top of that, it took them an hour after I reserved the room on priceline to check me in. And there wasn't any wash clothes to shower with, so I had to use my hand...yuck lol! 02/13/2015This is one of the most disgusting hotels I've ever stayed at. There's food or something splattered on the walls and furniture, cigarette burns on the furniture in a non-smoking room. The bathroom door doesn't shut and looks like it's has a lot of water damage and something splattered all over it. The door to the room doesn't latch properly. Has some of the rudest staff I've ever met.
review_content_20: I have always trusted the Biltmore name....until now. Booked this dump from online pictures that were as usual pretty good and saw it didn't have as many stars but a bad Biltmore beats most other chains hands down. This was by far the nastiest place I have ever tried to stay...room numbers ripped off doors....mold and mildew in drooping ceiling tiles in hallway...dirtiest cafe with the worst service...waitress actually came out holding food and chewing it to ask for our money before we even ate. No tv remote...no elevators...lamps looked dangerous to operate....and within 10 minutes of check in a man knocked on the door saying he left his knife on the bed...was it still there. Honestly we thought we were on a comedy tv show it was so bad. STAY AWAYSounds like the people who are complaining had one of the rooms where you have an entry that leads outside. We always request one of the rooms in the "middle" overlooking the indoor pool. Extremely spacious and comfortable. Friendly staff. Pet friendly. The pools are always clean. It is an older hotel that appears to have been an extremely nice place years ago. Affordable rates. Trucker friendly also.Check in is sssssssssllllllllooooooowwwwww. People are nice. They need a motivated building maintenance person who can do the little things like put plates over the outlets. I think people are being over critical. Room is dated and so is the facility. The thing is, you are getting what you pay for. It is a fair room at a fair price.I'm writing this for the soul purpose to help prevent the spread of bed bugs to future customers. This place is disgustingly dirty. Since our one night stay have been battling bed bugs in our home. This 50$ hotel now has cost over 200$$$ in repercussions, not to mention the depression that comes with no sleep and feeling dirty all the time. So disappointed a place like this is open for business. I've already filed a complaint with the ok health department.I swear something ate me alive in that horribly stiff bed! Our group reserved three rooms with five people to a room, and they charged for each person, but they only gave us two breakfast tickets per room despite this! those of us who ate there had a buffet style with only scrambled eggs, burnt sausage and brick biscuits. they also charged us a surprise 75 dollar deposit per room and said nothing about this! we had to find out about this from our bank that told us of our overdraft! if you even touched the thermostat, you would be rewarded with an ear piercing whisle from the vent, and each room only had two towels, and housekeeping refused to bring more, despite reserving FIVE TO A ROOM! no stars!Their advertising is all the exact opposite from what they really DO NOT offer.Their photos in their website do match what is really here. #1: Pillow-top mattress tops, NOT TRUE. #2:Air-conditioning, COOL AIRFLOW IS NOT air-condtioning! #3:If you desperately need a refrigerator, THERE ARE NONE! We were forced to keep filling the tub up with ice. This sucked!! #4:Room came w/o one HANGAR. #5:Not enough electrical outlets. #6:dusty old carpeting in the halls and odd smells walking down several hallways. #7: We just found out that our door lock doesn't work, YIKES! This sappy out-dated hotel is not worth your hard earned money. SAVE YOUR $$$. This hotel wouldn't get even one star-rating. We know in the future which hotel we will pass on. Most hotels offer free wifi, we will definitely go there.Filthy, bad service, no A/C, drug needles found in rooms, hastle for a refund. Would not recommend to anyone.Do not stay here. We were passing through and needed a place to sleep for the night so we came here. We got a rate for a room with 2 queen beds for $59.99. The guy at the front desk had me sign stating that I was paying $59.99 only to find out in the morning that they were going to charge an extra $10 and say it was "taxes". Why not just include the tax into the rate of the room at the time of payment so we know what we are being charged for? It doesn't make sense to me. Avoid this establishment!Where to begin? We just got home from two nights stay in the Biltmore Hotel in OKC. I was pretty horrified - first, when I called to make our reservations. Their system was down, she asked me to call back. I called back the next day and asked for the $49.99 rate as seen on a billboard, she said, "We are talking those down." Well, they are not down yet, so she did honor it after asking if I was out of state. No, I am not. "Well, she said, they are for out of state people." They do not say that. We got the $49.99 rate. we got there, waited in line a long time, took a long time to process, none of their office equipment was working .... printer, etc. They told us we would be in a certain room. We went to that room and tried to open the door, but it was locked a person (we were unsure if it were a man or a woman) said it was their room. Back down we go to get another room. The room was very warm....too warm and not super clean. There was no hand towels, no clock, two irons and an ironing board. ( I would have gladly traded an iron for a clock). The room had roaches and the BED WAS HORRIBLE! Neither of us slept much that first night, but the second night, we took the mattress off the hideabed and put it on our bed along with the cushions of the couch. We slept better, but ... can you imagine having to do that ?? The stairs were horribly dangerous with some rubber edges that were loose and dangling.You could see light around the doors AND one of our windows was open. We would have liked to have had the room coolers, but that was just weird! We turned down the heat, but it never cooled off. Did I mention roaches???? ugh.You get what you pay for. I thought this was like the Biltmore in Phoenix, I guess NOT!! Not impressed, will not go back. I certainly would not like people to think that represents OKC. It was noise, too.The only thing good about this hotel was the price. $89.99 per night. Office staff was dressed sloppy, they didn't get up to even help you. My room was not cleaned on Saturday, which was no big deal, but I needed clean towels and they would not bring them to me. The next day during checkout I told the "manager" and she told me we don't send anyone into the halls at night because it's dangerous. What does that mean? Halls smell terrible and the carpet is stained in every hall I was in. Never again will I stay in this hotel. It's not worth saving $20 per night.I would like to start out by saying, all these reviewers are complaining just to complain. I mean who looks behind the headboard anyway? We came here with a group of girls for the night since backstreet boys were in concert. Our first room had to be switched because we found food in it and a few personal belongings. Annoying? No. Odd? Yes. Our second room was fine. Yes the halls have a odd smell and yes the carpets were a little filthy but hey... you get what you pay for. Overall? It was fine. The room was clean, maybe not sterile, but clean. I'd argue that paying top dollar may not even get you sterile. Staff was friendly, no one busted our chops about anything. We opted to skip out on the breakfast and explore okc for a restaurant known for good food. Still not complaining. We were happy to get a nice breakfast outside of the hotel. It's an old building so don't expect the ritz. By the way, it is people who are disgusting, not the hotel. We watched the staff clean the bedroom next to us and they were scrubbing the floors. Definitely come here if you are looking for a cheap hotel for the night and don't want to complain about EVERY LITTLE THING. Can't go wrong for $50. Time to go get checked for herpes, hepatitis, HIV, and grab a tetanus shot after being at this dump!One of the worst hotels ever. Only one person at the desk while a line of customers waiting to get helped. The room was $59 for 1 night but not worth it. Security was loud and was banging on doors at 2am next door asking the people next. The room smelled like cigaretts and the decor was very old. It looked like this hotel was 60 years old. Still had old 1980's bulky tvs in there. I didnt think these existed anymore. People walking outside the hallways were load at 2am. Wish I would of paid a few more dollars and stayed at a different hotel. I would never go back to this hotel ever again.The foulest, dirtiest shanty hotel I've ever been in. This isn't a cheap room with little thrills. It's a room that was maybe nice when Nixon was president but has fallen apart and never been repaired and hardly cleaned. Stained comforter, thread bare carpet. Our non smoking room that reeked of smoke. The check in guy who took 30 minutes to check us in. Awful all around. 50$??? Should have been 29.99$Been here twice. Pretty good hotel. Have had the experience others have. Staff is friendly, they offer free wifi. It doesn't take much to please me. Overall it's a pretty nice place.There are no words to express how bad this establishment is, from filthy dirty, stained carpet in the hallways, stained, nasty mattresses under 'mattress' protectors. Dirty, stained, nasty bathrooms in the rooms, 'interesting' smells throughout the entire hotel. Cop cars outside all night with drug dogs going crazy outside and inside the hotel. Not to mention that they take your driver's license to copy it front and back when you check in (WHY???)...........they did not return the driver's license, however, they knew they had it. No attempt to put a note under the door of our room, call us on our cell phone (they gathered more information on me than my hospital or bank has on me upon check in). They also didn't try to find our vehicle to get the driver's license back to us. They add an additional charge to your credit card, you HAVE to check out at the desk in the morning to get the 'charge' taken off your card. Nobody left a message in the system to have them return the card when we checked out. When we discovered the card was missing (While trying to get on our cruise ship) They knew they had it, even read my hubby's legal name off the card to my sister. We were told we had to drive back to the hotel to get it........WTH??? The day we were driving back from Galveston after the cruise, I called to make sure somebody would have the card to give to me. NOBODY knew where it was, they denied they had it in their possession. So after calls to my sister to find out which hotel staff she talked to (REALLY??? LIKE WE HAD A NAME)it took them 3 hours to locate the card............get this, it wasn't in a secure, locked safe.....LORD. We were told at check in there was a free breakfast in the morning. However, they told us later at night that we booked thru Expedia, so did not qualify for the breakfast I also could not get a receipt upon check in because I booked thru expedia. The next morning I asked where the coffee was located, the girl told me (at 6:30 am) on 2/23 that I could not have coffee because I booked thru expedia. WOW. DO NOT GO HERE, it's nasty. we decided the breakfast was probably not safe to eat if the kitchen was as dirty as the entire place. So we left and went to a restaurant. This is a poorly ran hotel, staff is rude and not helpful. I called to get a corporate number, or a manager. THe manager was never in, or had just left. A one point, she was 'on another line' but when I called back to talk to her 15 minutes later, she didn't come in until 3pm. They told me they have no corporate office, nobody manages them. I cannot find a number to get hold of a corporate staff person. Believe me, this is not the place for you to stay. We would have changed hotels, but we arrived later in the day and had 17 people in our party. So we suffered thru it.One of the worst places I have ever stayed in if it was not for only one night and so late would have gone elsewhere. Room was old and not too cleanThis ain't the Taj Mahal. And that's what's so great about it. The Biltmore has perfectly fine accommodations, but it's going to be authentic down-home. You're going to see lots of trucks, horse trailers, etc., from all the people who attend the many horse shows in OKC. If you're in search of a good place to stay that offers an incredible people-watching and culture-absorbing experience compared to your local Marriott, this is the place.We went to the Biltmore Hotel tonight with a Groupon for the Brandywine dining room. Pure authenticity. Cattlemen and horse women were there from fairgrounds events. Three guys from the oil fields trudged in, branded in red corporate coveralls. A waitress entertained us with her charm, but also had us feeling that the check might not have exactly added up right in or favor (it was fine). She also gleefully handed us an extra to-go container to fill up on the salad bar before we left. When I thought I had lost my keys, other diners interjected friendly jabs when I remembered that I left my coat. If you have visitors looking for real Oklahoma dining, I'd recommend Cattlemen's, of course, and the Biltmore -- especially when there's a horse or livestock show in town. The Biltmore may have a name that bespeaks a certain expectation of accommodations. That is a disconnect that they have to deal with. But if you're an unpretentious, curious or adventuresome traveler, this is a great hotel if you want to get a sense of Oklahoma as a unique place.Not horrible, but doubtful we'd stay again. As others have mentioned, the hotel definitely looks like it was really nice and high-end once. It hasn't been updated at all and, at least in our room, that seems to have included the beds. One was virtually unusable because of the busted springs -- the foot slanted down like a ramp when you sat on it. (We let the dog sleep on that one.) There was some horse show or convention or some such going on so the hotel was crowded and the walls are paper-thin. We heard everyone around us coming, going, having sex, etc. The room was spacious and clean, which was nice, but the heat was totally wacky and we went from freezing cold to boiling hot and back all night long. The shower was very high (a plus when travelling with a tall man, like I do) but the pressure was pretty poor.They DO allow pets for a $25 fee (NOT for free, contrary to another review), which was our main reason for staying there, along with close proximity to the freeway and a place to park our rental moving truck.. Hotels.com was unaware of the two-animal limit when I made the reservation (we had a dog, three cats and two birds) but the front desk agreed to look the other way and let us stay anyway. (Which is good, since I'd already paid for the room.) The girl said she was upgrading us and giving us a nicer room that overlooked the indoor pool. I'm sure her intentions were good, but our windows were literally RIGHT above the pool and we woke far earlier than we intended to thanks to kids splashing around in the water. We also had a lot of stuff to carry in (luggage and pet stuff) and our room was upstairs and a little bit of a walk down the hall which was a little inconvenient. Not her fault, I suppose, I should have requested a downstairs room.We stayed here because the cheaper hotels in the area were booked. I understand why. Wouldn't stay again if we could avoid it.We were told the room was a certain price, then found out they charged $25 more. We needed ice after a long day of travel. We went to get ice and ended up going to 3 different ice machines. The first was broken and rusty, the second one wasn't even there, and the third worked but we had to go to a separate building.Walking into the building we noticed a thick haze of smoke. We had to walk up the filthy, gum stained stairs to get to our room. We noticed that the room numbers on some of the doors were nearly falling off.Our room seemed ok at first until we got settled in. The beds didn't have bed skirts so the outdated blue box spring is visble.There was some strange red/orange crusty stain on the ceiling. Pasta sauce? Blood? Who knows...The nightstand door didn't shut. The nightstand itself had scuffs, and burn marks in it. The wall had holes from former fixtures and they didn't bother to fill them in.The floor lamp had drink or food crust on its' base.The fridge was nice and cold but the door had fingerprints and dirt. The desk lamp was connected to a power strip that was dangling mid-desk. The desk chair and lounge chair were scuffed and faded. It was like Grandma's furniture circa 1980.Don't even get me started on the bathroom. You may want to wear flip flops in the bathroom/shower as the grip on the bottom of the tub was a lovely shade of DIRT from past guest's feet.The carpet. Oh, that lovely forrest green carpet that probably hasn't been cleaned since this place opened... There was a white crusty substance on the floor next to the window. That was an area we avoided.The pluses: They are pet friendly and pets stay free, the AC is great, the microwave was spotless, and it was a place to stay the night.
review_content_40: Stayed here one night with my son. Keys to the room wouldn't work. Noted 2 reports of guest property theft at front desk by the time I completed check-in. Room smelled terribly and the odor has permeated both my clothes and luggage. Bathroom dirty with stains on counter. Housekeeping entered room next morning at 8am and, after I asked them to leave, lurked outside room until we left. Gets 1 star for front desk courteousness in resolving key issue. Cannot recommend this establishment to friends, family, or complete strangers. My son summed it up best when he said, "Hasta la vista, crappy hotel."Horrible experience. While the room was decent you could tell it's age. The sheets were stained and the bed spread smelly. Our non smoking room had clearly been smoked in before. The walls and doors are very thin and you can hear EVERYTHING in the halls and in the breezeways and rooms around you. It was very loud and sleezy. The pools were gross as well as the hot tub. You definitely get what you pay for. Management refused to give us a refund when we said we were leaving. DO NOT STAY HERE.Older unclean feeling room. Ceiling tiles in bathroom were the regular drop in kind allowing access to the attic, and letting any psycho axe murderer types to come into your room in the middle of the night while you are asleep. Door didn't lock easily and still didn't inspire confidence once it did. The also do not allow concealed weapons, and the general consensus is you may need one. Also, the security guard from the adjoining night club had id's and credit cards from customers booking rooms right in front of me. Didn't know what that was all about, could only guess and when I did it creeped me out. I would probably spring for the extra $10-15 and gave peace of mind with name brand chain.This hotel is a relic of a bygone era, and not a good relic. If I were to guess, this hotel saw its peak in the late 1970s. The rooms have large glass windows which face the parking lot. Cars in the parking lot may as well be driving through your room. We checked in late through the hotel's website, which required us to wait until registration received a fax from a third party. Our bathroom featured a no-slip bath mat with black mold on the back of it, no washcloths, and no exhaust fans. The staff is courteous and polite, which is the one positive factor about this hotel. Save yourself the headache and stay in a chain hotel.I AM THE MOST IRRATE CUSTOMER RIGHT NOW! DO NOT GIVE BUSINESS TO THIS PREJUDICE HOTEL!!!! I booked a travel package on Travelocity.com for my business colleague, and he stayed at the Biltmore for 6 nights. I spoke to the "Manager" shortly after making this reservation and she advised me she found the reservation and everything would be taken care of rest assured. Today, a day after, my colleague calls to say he has been locked out of his room because they did not find the reservation. After having had spoken to the manager. So I call to confirm that I made this reservation, the lady was very INCOMPETENT and couldn't find his reservation. They are trying to make him pay double, after my card has been charged. I called back after the lady hung up on me, this time with traveocity on 3-way, she said I was the problem and hung up YET AGAIN! I have been dealing with this for the past 3 hours today!!! RIDICULOUS! NEVER STAY HERE. THEY ARE RACIST AND DON'T FOLLOW GOOD BUSINESS PRACTICES! 2 THUMBS DOWN!This complaint is about the Biltmore Hotel, 401 S Meredian Ave, OKC, OK. Their phone number is 405-947-7681. I was at the hotel this past weekend along with a number of friends. We were there for a conference in another location. Some checked in 9/19/13 while most checked on 9/20/13. This was the worst hotel I have ever been in health and safety wise. Our rooms had roaches, ants and I overheard one woman waiting to complain about bedbugs in her room. One of the conference speakers had black mold on the ceiling tiles in his bathroom. When he complained maintenance brought in other tiles to replace the ones with black mold. My room had several dead roaches. We spoke to a few other guests during the stay who complained that they were shown 3-4 rooms before accepting the one they did stay in for the weekend. They stated that all of the rooms that they were shown were full of roaches. The room I was to stay in Sunday night was horrible. It was 414. When the guests checked in they discovered ants crawling on the night stand. They called the front desk and maintenance came in and sprayed chemicals behind the night stand. The same thing occurred on Friday night. Saturday night the ants were not as bad. Then they woke up Sunday morning. There were ants on the nightstand, crawling on the beds, in the bathroom and worse. One person went to take a shower and discovered ants all over the shower. Then the other went into the bathroom and observed ants crawling on the vanity, on her toothpaste tube and INSIDE the cap of the deodorant. Upon further checking ants were discovered in just about everything. The ants were in the suitcases and boxes. We were unable to obtain better quality rooms at this hotel so did not stay by choice. The promoter who was running the conference where the speakers were was paying for the rooms and she spent countless hours trying to get better rooms. The State Fair was the same weekend so she was unable to move everyone to a different hotel. Another speaker was in room 420 and had his prescription medicine stolen from the refrigerator. I was in a room, 422, with another speaker. When she arrived in the room the smell of stale cigarettes, mold and mildew was so bad she had to get something to try and clear the air. It wasn't safe to leave the doors open to try and air it out due suspicious activity in the area, including males walking the parking lot with baseball bats for protection. We had dead roaches in our room, but I have allergies and had respiratory trouble the entire time I was there and am still fighting it. Another speaker had a room that was dirty, smelled and didn't even have spreads on the bed. Another one had trouble with her room as well as did yet another speaker. The chlorine smell coming out of the room where the pools were located and banquet type tables was overpowering and made your eyes water. We were told the hotel has a new owner and he purchased the hotel two weeks ago. We had one manager, Morris, who assisted us upon checkout because we did leave early and Ms. Jones did received a full refund for the two extra days we were going to stay - the previous Thursday and the coming Monday. He was helpful eventually however, while several of us were speaking with him an unruly tall, thin, dark-skinned Middle Eastern or Egyptian type of male burst into the manager's office screaming and yelling and pointing his finger at us individually in a threatening manner. We weren't intimidated like your average person would have been. When he burst into the room screaming I believed him to be a threat as he lunged toward one of us. I believed he was going to grab him by the arm while poking his finger in his face while screaming at us and calling us names. I told him to back up and take his finger out of his face. He was screaming that he's a manager and we were to leave the hotel. We told him no because we had not checked out and one of us was still discussing the refund with Morris. Morris told him numerous times to leave and that everything was fine but he wouldn't listen. He stuck his finger in a lady's face as well while shouting for us to leave. Morris physically put him out of the office and shut the door. Then he was able to discuss and give one of us a refund for the two extra nights we had planned to stay. When that was settled on person and I were in the room discussing the health issues with Morris and we tried to show him photographs of a room, but Morris said he didn't want to see photographs of any rooms and that it wasn't necessary. He apologized for the quality of the rooms which was too late. The younger manager burst into the room a second time screaming at one of us to leave. He created a disturbance and lunged at one of the females while pointing his finger in her face. He was so close I don't know how he managed to not assault her by striking her on the nose with his hand. She politely asked for his name several times and he refused to give his name.I feel bad writing this review because the supervisor was so helpful in refunding my money when we left after only a couple of hours but I feel compelled to warn others. Especially those traveling with kids and/or pets. The minute we checked into our room I felt like I was getting bitten by something every few seconds. Then I find stains, smears on mattresses, walls, etc. The mattresses looked new but everything else looked about 30 years old and was falling apart. And they told me this was one of their renovated rooms. I can't even imagine what the old ones must look like. Don't let the website fool you like it did me!Was at this hotel for an event January 2011Check in was easy. Have been at this hotel many times. Bathroom was remodeled since last visit (2009)-well doneNew bed and sheets. Old model TV not in good shape(upgrades w/LCD not costly).Had dinner first night in Brandywine room-VERY good steak-salad bar was not as good as 7-11--weird---soft ice cream machine -broken.Breakfast buffet is very good. Morning server Sandra is the best.Lunch buffets were all OKHad dinner again Brandywine room. Very good chicken fried steak--again salad bar -@###$&^%%-but ice cream machine fixed.computer room needs overhaul.Meeting rooms were comfortable & well appointed.Jay at front desk very good.Not the best--comfortable--will be there againIf it was an option, I wouldn't even give this place a star. This place is a dump.. We checked in at 4am after traveling straight through from LAX. We checked in, and went to our room, after paying $120 for us, and our two dogs (not worth the price).The carpet was FILTHY. The room smelled musty, and you could clearly see spots where past animals had relieved themselves. After 30 minutes, and an attempt at a shower, my husband packed our stuff and demanded for a refund! The manager was not pleased. We left in a hurry, with a bite on my leg, and a rash under my arm. It's safe to say that we WILL never stay here EVER again. They either need to renovate, or have the place condemned. Yuck. PS: we're still waiting for our refund.You have GOT to be kidding. How is this place even still in business? It's a complete dump. After about 5 hours at the airport waiting for United to get their act together, a bunch of us got sent to the Biltmore. Yeah, thanks United. My room smelled so strongly of cat urine, as did the room of a fellow United victim, we elected to hang out on the slightly less-fetid couches in the lobby until our shuttle came. The one nice thing was that the guy at the desk brought us pillows. This place was otherwise gross, disgusting and smelly.Hotel is a throwback to better times, if you consider 1975 better. We'll see how breakfast fairs in a/m. Heard it is decent. Update: breakfast buffet was very good! All in all it was an OK experience. I believe the property has in the past been a Hilton and I think a Radisson, so it was quality at one time. Remember, you get what you pay for.I liked the place! I was there for a conference and I thought it was the perfect spot for it. I was a bit concerned by the negative reviews I saw before I went but found I was pleasantly surprised.It is a big place spread out on what I would guess 10 acres. With 500+ rooms and the old 2 story layout meant conference people were not crammed together. I was on the 2nd floor and I think my room was a little nicer. Many, especially those with mobility problems, prefer to stay on the ground floor and park by their rooms so I think the upper rooms maybe used less.I had a king sized bed, coffee table, couch, desk, fridge, microwave, iron and board, hair dryer soaps, shampoos, TV and strong wireless internet. The room and sheets were clean. The food was good and there were many many eating places nearby.Negatives: stupid door lock card often took several tries to get green light and open. On a couple of days of my 6 day stay it was mid afternoon before my room was cleaned. Front desk was not that knowledgeable on local restaurants and bus routes.It definitely seems like a place that was really really nice in the early 80s, and they havent done a thing to it since. I felt like I went back in time. But for the very cheap price this place was a great value. Not very many people staying there during our visit, but room was clean, comfy and big with plenty of room to spread out, and we could walk out our back door to one of the pools. Lots of different pools to use with a very warm indoor pool if you like that. So if you dont really care about trendy decorations give it a try.stayed here twice, cheap, and not as bad as others, but everyone has they're own opinionsTerrible customer service. The Super 8 next door has cheaper & cleaner rooms and a staff that seems to care you exist.Overcrowded during stay. Walls are thin so your able to hear everyone walking and talking up and down the halls at all hours and when it's quiet in the halls you hear the cars or sirens going outside. Yeah this place is somewhat nice in it's old time feel. But this is a one time kind of stay! I do not recommend to an outsider to stay here unless you like lots of people/kids roaming around and noise which never seemed to end. Thought coming here to an indoor pool for kids would be awesome since it's been around 40 degrees outside, well that's not true either. Yes the pool was heated but due to overcrowding in such a small area and so many kids not obeying the rules of the pool with no one to help enforce them, my kids didn't enjoy their time at the indoor pool. The photos on their website make it seem way nicer than it really is. From now on I'll stay at the Hilton Garden's in Norman. Same price but so much nicer by far.Wow. If your neck isn't red, you might want to get a sunburn before you come in here. I love it, but it's too deep a dive for most dive bar fans. The Biltmore is an old Hilton that is the official hotel of every horse show and rodeo held in the city, and it seems like there's one every week. The cast of wild, seedy characters here will change your world view if you've never known a real cowboy. Staying at the hotel gets you a coupon for a free drink here. Their only food item, a shrimp cocktail, was actually remarkably fresh, one of the better ones I've had in the area. No smoking, but it doesn't matter because so many thousands of cigarettes gave their lives in here over the years. The hotel has three bars and two restaurants, I think. They are all memorable, and the place used to be nice. I would stay here if I needed a hotel in the city, it's so cheap and has so much free entertainment.

review_content: Is this the best hotel you've ever stayed in? No...unless you stay at places that leave the light on for you.Is this the best service in OKC? Yes. Oh, you think the Hiltons are better? Wrong. The Marriotts? Not even close.You see, I put in the comments that 'I sleep better with Nicholas Cage watching over me.' What did this hotel do? They had Nick Cage there with a halo keeping me safe at night. Kudos to you OKC Sheraton staff. Y'all rock harder than Van Halen."Meh. I've experienced better."I've spent several weeks here and none of them are what I'd qualify as positive experiences.The staff on the main floor is very helpful.On other floors, nobody will help you. If you call to ask for... let's say, toothpaste, you'll have to call again. It took 3 calls to get toothpaste. Two calls to get cutlery.One week I checked in and thought "Oh, they must have given me the wrong room" because there was somebody else's room service remnants on the floor in front of the door. I had to actually push the tray a few inches out of the way to get into the door. That was my room and that tray of dirty dishes stayed in front of my door for 20-30 hours. I'm not sure when it left because it happened while I was at my 2nd day of work.Another time I got this room with a janky door. Every morning I got to fight it and repeatedly test if it was actually closed, again when I'd leave for dinner/activities at night. That was lovely. They "didn't have any other rooms" although it wasn't listed as Sold Out when I checked 30mins after they told me that.If you stay on the 2nd floor, that's where the gym is. That sounds good if you're into working out, which I am, but it's not. Any time somebody wants to workout, you hear and feel it. Yes, the ground moves and you get that lovely treadmill belt-scraping sound. I string of obscenities would leave my mouth when somebody went in for an 11pm workout.They did remodel the bar area while I was there and it's much improved.The Renaissance across the street was my preferred hotel for this project.I was a recent guest at the Sheraton for a weekend away with a friend. I paid for the 2-nights up front through a 3rd-Party website. The stay itself was very nice and the hotel was very nice. The staff I met were very pleasant. My issue comes afterwards. My friend who showed up to the hotel before me gave her CC for incidentals. After we checked out the hotel actually charged her CC for the 2-night stay after I had already paid upfront for the room. I notified the hotel the day after check out, they apologized and assured me the money would be refunded asap. I thanked them for their quick response and had mentioned that the sooner the better since their mistake had over drafted my friends bank account. Fast Forward a week later and still no refund. I notified the hotel the next week to ask what happened. The manager I spoke with apologized and said he had forgotten to "save" it last week when he entered the refund. He then entered the refund again and I received a confirmation email. What I noticed was the amount refunded was for about $30 less than the amount taken out. I called back to question and the manager reminded me that I had ordered 2 drinks through room service and that was the difference in the refund.Now I agree that I did order 2 drinks that cost $30, but my argument here is that the Sheraton screwed up twice, once charging my friend for the 2-nights (which put her bank account into over draft and charged her $40) and then second forgetting to input the refund initially and having to have myself call back a week later to ask again about the missing money. My issue is that with the 2 accidental screw ups (things happen I understand), would it not be a very minor issue for the hotel to simply "comp" the $30 worth of drinks. Maybe as a "We apologize" type gesture? Especially since my friend now has to pay $40 for the over-draft penalty. When I brought this up to the manager I was responded with a scoff and a "I'll refund the drinks" reply. The money is back now but after being in the customer service industry for quite a few years now building custom homes in Dallas I feel that the little things is what make a good experience. Things happen and I was not upset about the initial over charge. My issue is the way it was handled by the Manager I spoke with, J.St.Claire after bringing my concerns to their attention not once, but multiple times. -Chad RestovichThis location meets my basic needs. It is clean, conveniently located, has comfortable beds and reasonable rates. Other notables - rooms are spacious - SPG members get a free bottle of water - the lobby is nice - it has a large business center - free USA Today papersMeh, I have experienced better - the rooms are in need of updates (doors are very aged and chipping) - the hallways show aging- when trying to get assistance with getting a taxi, Concierge seriously shoves Airport Shuttle down your throat. I walked up on the hard sell to another guest who refused and when I asked for assistance with getting a taxi, I received the same spill. She supposedly went to check and came back to say the Airport Shuttle would be the quickest option. I told her I would get an Uber instead. When I walked out there were several taxis. Guess the commission or incentives for Airport Shuttle are better. Eek!I have good and bad things to say. I'll start with the bad. We asked and was charged for a king size bed. When we arrived to the room realized that they gave us a room with double beds. They also put us in room 718 that happens to be directly next to the elevators. We could hear the elevators being used all night. I put the do not disturb sign on door and it was ignored. There was a tissue holder without a tissue box in it. Not really a big deal but it's weird. Good things. The room was about $150 a night. Not a bad price for location. Staff was very nice. Parking was $10 for 24 hours. That's pretty good price and convenient. There was Starbucks coffee in the room plus two free bottles of water. Doesn't sound like a big deal but if you have some drinks the night before it comes in handy. Last thing is the bar it's pretty awesome. The bartenders were really great.I'm a Hyatt girl but this place makes me want to reconsider my life choices. Pet friendly hotels are limited at times and I didn't realize I could stay somewhere as nice as this with my child of another species. Front desk staff was amazing and my girl Linka was a huge fan of their hospitality with the treats. Rooms were excellent in the cleanliness factor. THEIR BEDS, OH HEAVENS GIRL. These may have been better than my top choice in hotel accommodations. I always have a problem of pillows being too fluffy, then waking up only then to have a sore neck. These? Say no more, friend. The mattress itself feels like it's enveloping you. To be honest, I was hesitant at first because I felt like I was cheating but I left one happy guest. Easy walking access to Bricktown as well.Sometimes I see three stars for a hotel and think folks are either being a little harsh or too generous on average.  The Sheraton in OKC earns a solid three stars.  Was it the worst hotel I've stayed in?  No.  Was it the best?  By no means.The good - the staff was certainly friendly and pleasant.  The club option is mostly what you expect, and the food they provided in the club was decent.  The breakfast in the restaurant downstairs has an omelette chef, and that's always a plus in my book.The mediocre - This hotel is full of mediocre.  While the staff was pleasant, they knew very little about what was and was not going on in the hotel.  We happened to be staying there when Obama was in town and staying at the Sheraton.  I understood some of the confusion while the president was around and the secret service was keeping everyone intentionally confused.  After he left, they had no reason to not know things.  We mostly struggled with when and where food was available.  Because they were taking up the top two floors of the hotel, we were reassigned to a different room.  I struggled for a week to get my bill corrected.  Poor communication was the biggest barrier to wrapping it up.  The pool is outdoors on the third floor.  That was kind of cool, and also extremely hot.  It was a pretty small pool.The bad - I never like saying anything negative about the cleaning staff, but this place was not the cleanest.  I don't know if the hotel was so full that they had that much to clean or if the crew was that slack on what they were doing.There are a lot of hotels in this area.  The Sheraton may not be your best choice for being close to the convention center or Bricktown.Had a wonderful stay. Extremely clean, friendly staff, wonderful food and fabulous location. Never had a single problem. Would recommend this hotel to anyone!Staff is awesome. Upgraded our room and gave us free breakfast and evening snacks. I think the young man at the front desks name was Colin, very nice. The rooms were not quite as good as the rest of the hotel but made up for it everywhere else.Checking in here was such a pleasant surprise. This has to be one of the friendliest hotel staffs I've ever encountered. If you are staying in downtown OKC and want to be near Bricktown, this is a well run hotel and staff. We were traveling with our dog and they had a nice dog area with all the clean up accessories. The neighborhood is the best place in the city if you are traveling for fun and leisure. We haven't been to the OKC memorial yet, but it is only a few blocks away. Austin, who tends bar in the Aria Lounge inside the hotel, was so friendly. Outstanding service! Great at making menu recommendations. The bar manager, didn't catch his name, was very attentive as well. Looking forward to visiting again!Stayed here a few times and enjoyed it. The only downside is the distance to the bar district is about a 10 minute walk. And in OK heat that might as well be 4 miles in the summer. The bar downstairs is nice and they have good rates, but I recommend staying closer to Downtown.Just pay a little more and stay somewhere else.Upon arrival the valet told us we would have to use them to park our car overnight to the tune of $25. Why? Because their garage was being renovated so they had no self park. Alternate option? Walk in the dark to the Amtrack station and park there for $10. Not knowing where it was or how far the attendant said we should valet. Went to check in and the check in person said it is only a block (still it is dark and you don't have parking because of your own construction) but no help there we had to get our car out of valet and trek to the Amtrak (welcome to Oklahoma?).Get to our room and I loved the shabby chic wooden front on the bathroom sink. Oh wait that wasn't meant to be like that (try a paint job folks, pretend you care) and then the awful bed with even worse pillows that were lumpy and gave me a terrible neck ache.I wake up to have a nice shower and that wasn't going to happen either as I turn to face the piercing shower head water I find pink bacteria/mold in the shower head. Let's not forget the peeling laminate on the tables in the bar....just say no.The location is perfect for any Bricktown happenings!  It's clean.  The lobby looks great if you are without kids: dining, drinking, computer access.It's an 80s updated hotel.  They can't help it.  There is only so much you can do for a hotel like this.  It's not a place to bring the kids.  2 double beds and no King suite available.  Good for them though for being 90% occupied and nowhere to move us.  If you grew up by an airport & are missing home, this room is for you! Otherwise, DO NOT ALLOW THEM TO PUT YOU BY THE ELEVATOR. It sounds like jets are flying over all night.Youngest child decided the floor was a better choice than having to share a double bed with the sibling.- Housekeepers still cleaning rooms at 10:45pm and making a bunch of noise in the hallway outside my room.- Stayed here twice now (travel on business) and 2/3 showers had issues- Bathrooms are tinyProbably switching to the Skirvin Hilton for next week. (Update 5/10: Skirvin has banquet space on the top floor and parties with live bands are allowed to run well into the 11pm hour on week nights which is a total deal breaker for 12th floor guests, major fail for a business hotel. and 100% of my bed sheets had at least one hole in them.)Update 5/10: I took my business to the Ambassador Hotel (Marriott Autograph collection) and never looked back.  They are the best, almost like a throw back to good, caring hospitality. Ask for Karina at the desk and she will take care of you.The hospitality at this Sheraton exemplifies why I love the Starwood brand hotels. If SPG chose one hotel as a model to train all others on customer service, this would be IT. Upon arriving, the front desk staff noticed I had a rough day of travel and did all they could to make me feel at ease once I arrived. (Thank you Colin!!). Concierge staff was fantastic with advice on places to check out and restaurant picks. Hospitality staff was patient and helped us with our air conditioning and loaned us a wine cork so we could enjoy our bottle of wine. Thank you Sheraton staff, you are the reason why I'm a SPG fan for life!Lovely hotel but placed in an adjoining room with a paper thin door between us. The people in the next room started watching tv at 5am which we could clearly hear. It was at 5:30am when they started playing guitar and singing to warm up for the Voice auditions being held that day that I really got annoyed. The person on the desk just said sorryLove this place. It's in the perfect spot downtown. They don't try to rake you over the coals for parking either like some hotels we've stayed at. My only suggestion is a small fridge or larger ice bucket to keep drinks coldCame to see the ShineDown concert and stayed here. The staff are very professional and Kelly in the bar was great. The hotel needs some work. There was some loud noise just wailing from the plumbing or something. The front desk didn't know what it was. The curtains didn't even come close to blocking out the sun. The last thing you want the morning after a show is a big blast of sunlight. The dinning options are limited and they don't have anything that shows you what is around the hotel. Probably try a different one next time.For the money I'm paying to spend a few days here, I have to say overall I'm disappointed. First and foremost, there's no free wifi! $10 a day or $13 for "premium" access. Nearly every hotel in the country has free wifi, even the cheapest, yet this one does not. Also get ready to pay for parking. $10 a day self-park with only two free in and out passes, or you can pay $25 a day for valet with unlimited daily access. You don't know how frustrating it is to drive by miles and miles of open fields on the way to OKC only to pay for parking here. Le sigh. Okay, now the positive. The staff I met was friendly. The lobby is nice. The rooms are clean. The beds are comfy. Although the bathroom is tiny! Anyway, unless you HAVE to stay in downtown OKC, just find a nice Holiday Inn Express on the edge of town somewhere and drive in.DON'T USE THE VALET SERVICE!I was only here for a conference, so I don't have a full review of the hotel. The conference facilities were fine. The food was pretty good and the wait staff service was good. The room was very very cold, we asked twice for them to adjust the temp with no success. Bring a jacket, regardless of the time of year. The room would shake and rattle about every 4-5 minutes. I'm not sure what caused this, someone speculated it was due to the nearby construction. It wasn't a huge deal but it was a bit weird, almost like mini earthquakes. My biggest complaint is the valet service. You will have to wait 20-30 minutes for your car, regardless of time of day. I am not the only one that experienced this. There were 4 other people waiting and complaining as well. They have a text-to-retrieve feature that sounds cool, but doesn't speed up the process at all.  I strongly recommend not using them, it will cost you $15 plus tip and cost you lots of time and frustration.
review_content_20: Booked through hotwire for $105 for a Saturday night. The location was great . The lobby was very fancy, made someone who usually stays at the holiday inn feel a little out of place. Unfortunately, the room did not match the lobby. It was decorated very nicely and was very spacious. The white comforter had a couple dark stains on the top. The bathroom was tiny! To close the door you had to wedge yourself between the toilet and the sink. It was also very outdated. I loved being downtown and having the view. I also enjoyed the hotel bar. It was a little pricey but that is to be expected with hotel bars. They served a full menu 11am-midnight and had a small menu until 2am. We had a few appetizers and dessert there and everything was delicious!What is with all the negativity?  The people at Sheraton in town Sacra California right!  More people liking write negative!  They can tell my comments, as I one of only few writes positive, whether it be a hotel, a furniture store, a restaurant, a grocery store, so forth!Anyway, in 2004, was a Westin Hotel!  Year 2005 was switching over from Westin to Sheraton!  In fact, when I made the reservation for 2005, of course since I always send CASHIER CHECK from my bank, I had big overpayment since when was Westin was one price, when changed to Sheraton was different price!Being a Starwood Preferred Guest member, I know is either Handicap Room or Club Level access!  Cannot have both!  So when stayed 2007, ask for Handicap Room knowing for safety reasons, can buy my own meals!  Yet when checked in, maybe because I showed my Starwood Preferred Guest card, I got the Club Level access!  I think was also a handicap room, the silver support grab bars in the shower, by the toilet, by the bed!  They did provide a sit down shower chair!  Was room 1509, so fifteenth floor!  Only complaint and every hostess and every host at Club Level, year 2007, no hot foods at Club Level for hors doeuvres!  I use Club Level to my advantage, breakfasts and the hors doeuvres for suppers!  The Sheraton in Sacra knows this!  Every hostess and every host at Club Level in Sheraton OKC tell the guest when they fill out comment cards to "BACK ME UP ON THIS," complain of no hot food!  I could not since I had not paid the extra to have Club Level!  Other that fact, this an excellent hotel!  As say, anytime I been to fun Child Friendly OKC, I always stay here!The parking stinks in this part of okc. Prepare to pay $25 for valet. I booked on hot wire for $85 on a Sat night which wasn't bad for bricktown. The rooms were decent. Bed was comfortable.  Outside our door was a room service breakfast tray that was there from 3pm to 10pm. We could hear the elevators roaring up and down all day, night, and morning.  That might bother some. Didn't bother me to much. There is no free Internet here. The lobby and business area was modern and sleek.  The rooms were sort of sleek. They were dated yet updated meaning they had the nice bed and new furniture, cool wallpaper etc, but ceilings are short with popcorn on them. That's to be expected for an older hotel. The view was awesome of bricktown.  We were on the 13th floor. This hotel is good but not great. It is close to the action.Horrible experience. Staff was unhelpful and the room quality poor. Asked if there was an alternative to the valet parking, was told their were no nearby (covered) self parking areas while the employee took a personal cell phone call... There's a public garage attached by a (locked) skywalk across the street... As for the room, the wallpaper was peeling, the shower's water never got hot, and the elevators reeked of vomit. Gross. Checked out a day early; just couldn't stand it. Definitely not returning or recommending.Not bad, but not great either. The room was clean and the parking garage was not available. We parked right across the street for half the price. The breakfast in the morning was good with several options. Fresh omelets!Not expecting the Ritz, but expecting something better from a Sheraton branch. Stayed here over the weekend for a conference, the conference rooms ranged from humid and hot, to the arctic tundra. Bring your jackets just in case!The staff acted uppity; I may look young, but it doesn't mean I don't deserve some semblance of respect. Check in was an awful moment, because the staff kept skipping over me for other patrons. My friend's sheets had stains on it. The vent was dusty and black in our room. The view was nice though, we were facing the Devon tower and on the the upper floors. The redeeming quality could be the close proximity to Bricktown, but even then.INCREDIBLE STAFFThey were amazing. Brian and Kia with banquets were amazing. 5 stars to themMinus 1 star for the worst parking options:(I ordered the chicken walnut strawberry salad with balsamic vinaigrette. It was awesome with a couple of glasses of Chardonnay . Service was top notch thanks to Tiffany and Austin behind the bar.Dingy, dirty hotel that desperately needs a face lift.  Beds were comfortable but carpets were gross and there were stains on the ceiling, etc.  I had a short stay there but I believe it's location is pretty good with some good pubs and restaurants close by.  Since my stay was so short I didn't get out and just had a few adult beverages at the bar and their chicken club sandwich, which actually was pretty good.Clean rooms with new amenities. Carpet is relatively new without odor and the air filtration system is clean and fresh. The concierge and staff was warm and advisable on places to dine within the local area. Starbucks coffee in the room as well as a proper store adjacent to the hotel. Reasonable and clean place overall.I just opened a Yelp account because of this hotel. I paid more than $150 a night and all I got was noise. I was there 3 nights and didn't sleep at all the first 2. First there was a nearby service door by my room and we hear every single move outside. Then there was construction work noise starting at 6:00 am. Yes, somebody drilling right above my room woke us up at 6:00 am. After calling the front desk and explained the situation they were very nice and moved us to another room (that still had some noise but at that point it didn't really mattered any more). As of March 2013 they were renovating and it was all bit messy.  If you are looking for a good night sleep I suggest you try something else.I stayed here for three nights. The lobby was clean mediocre. The staff was friendly the service was ok. However, there were Problems during my stay. The room smelled like chemicals and carpets was dirty and there were stains. One annoyance was the lack of a refrigerator which I found out I had to pay to rent. When I ask for refrigerator they told me they were out of it and told me to wait until one was returned. That was last time that I heard from them. I headed to the nearest Walmart and bought an icebox. Secondly, the hairdryer was in absolutely filthy condition. It was covered in a film of greasy fat. I was appalled and requested for a replacement. However, the replacement was ALSO covered in fat and rusty. I think it was even worse shape. I gave up and did not ask for more. Thirdly, the iron was stinky. It worked properly for about 10 minutes then it started to spew out brown liquid. It was disgusting. I was lucky that I wasn't ironing my white dress shirt at that time. Finally, during Friday and Saturday nights, the hall ways were filled with loud noises. You could hear everything from loud door closing, screaming drunk people running up and down, and flushing toilets all night. The building came alive during night time. It was absolutely incredible.Next time I will definitely stay at a different hotel. P.S. This hotel charges you for parking each day. I recommend to park on the street because the parking building is just a big nest for pigeons and smells gross. Also, the internet is not free. they will charge for each day.Full disclosure:  after cancelling my initial reservation, I was rebooked via Priceline, as this was a professional trip and I wasn't the one paying. Unbeknownst to me prior to my arrival, and I'm not entirely sure how this could have happened, nor was I ever given an explanation, but I've deduced that the hotel went ahead and cancelled both reservations, after seeing two in my name. I'll give them the benefit of the doubt and say it was probably an honest mistake, but it was how they initially handled the situation that left a bad taste in the mouth. Hooboy.To make matters worse, due to an emergency, I ended up missing my scheduled departure to Oklahoma City (Iong story). I didn't even pack. Activate contingency plan. I got in my car after literally throwing anything within sight into a weekend bag and sped for 7.5 hours half asleep, wearing clothes from the night before, arriving at the hotel only an hour behind schedule, impressive given my state of mind that day. Needless to say, I showed up in the hotel lobby looking like hell had spat me back out.  I just wanted to check-in immediately, shower, put on clean clothes, and pass out. No such luck.Front desk gave me an eye roll and attitude right off the bat when I showed them my Priceline reservation (great customer service, you guys!). I got even more eye rolls and attitude when they couldn't find me in the system (awesome!). I was then told that it was my responsibility to contact Priceline (at this point, fine, whatever). Got in touch with a Priceline rep in a foreign country, who called the hotel. Ended up getting told by the Priceline rep (not once, but on two separate occasions) that everything had been sorted out. Front desk told me otherwise (twice), and that they had no clue what Priceline was talking about, basically saying that Priceline was talking to someone who didn't work at the hotel and that I was SOL, despite me confirming with Priceline repeatedly that I had booked this OKC location and they were in contact with the correct hotel. Which resulted in me hanging out awkwardly in the lobby as I handed over my cell phone and forced both parties (plus an invisible manager in a back office somewhere??) to sort out the mess out for the next half hour, because I'm sorry, I did NOT just take an unexpected 500+ mile roadtrip to be treated like an unwanted guest, and to be given the run-around!In the end, because I was so frustrated, I explained to them I was in town for business, not pleasure, and expressed my disappointment with how the situation was handled so poorly. Their demeanor did change, and they did their best to make up for it with an upgrade to the Club Level and comped wifi/parking, which was appreciated given all the stress that weekend. They get a YOU TRIED! star (as opposed to one) for that. Amenities were meh. I think the hotel was supposedly recently redesigned, but the furniture, sheets, and walls are already showing a lot of wear and tear. The in-house line of Sheraton toiletries feel cheap and terrible, especially when other hotels are going upscale. They were in the process of remodeling the parking garage and there was a staircase from the basement that went to absolutely nowhere...don't get lost in there late at night. A warning sign would have been nice.By checkout, most of the frustration had receded and had been mollified, although I couldn't quite forget how I was initially treated by the front desk at check-in. Hence this review. Avoiding this place the next time I'm in town. This is not how you run a hotel.This place is not worth the money.
