Please let me explain.My husband and I were going to celebrate my birthday in Bricktown and wanted a reasonably priced hotel for the short night we would be in downtown OKC (we live in Norman). After looking at prices online and realizing the Bricktown hotels were pretty pricey, we opted for the nearby Sheraton. I'm not used to staying in incredibly fancy hotels or demand perfection, but this hotel is awful.First of all, I made our reservations online via Expedia. I booked a King size bed. Upon check-in we had a 30 minute wait and were told that only two Queen beds were available. Not a deal breaker, but not what I paid for. Secondly, the room was not clean. Everything from the carpet to the linens to the coffee cups were dirty. Wallpaper throughout the room was coming unpeeled (is that a word?) and the finishes and hardware felt cheap and were loose (door knob in bathroom, etc.). The room did have a great A/C, which was needed in mid-July, and a TV...but other than that, incredibly unimpressive. The bed wasn't necessarily uncomfortable - but wasn't the best, either. Our room was located directly across from the maid and/or maintenance storage room (it has double doors). Every single time someone entered or left that room, they slammed the door and it was LOUD. We heard all the commotion, including carts being wheeled in and out, loud conversations between the staff, etc. We tried to sleep in the following morning but our attempt was unsuccessful because of the noise and obvious disregard for the paying guests. Avoid this hotel. Trust me. Stay at the Colcord Hotel which is just across the street. That's what we should have done - it was only $20 more and would have been a much, much better choice.Know how we're always remarking about the need of the half star ?  This place is a good example of how our prejudices bump these places down, while others get the bump-up (see Cheevers review). This place shows signs of being updated.  You can only dress up one of ye olde 80s-style Sheratons so much though: Van Gogh had to work with a  palette too, right ?This is a perfectly clean, centrally located (Ford Center, Bricktown, business district), strong 2.5 star property.  I frequently stay with Starwood.  This was such a points reservation as events were in town and the nightly rate would have been ~$200.  First, that's way too much in OKC.  Second, there are nicer hotels (even Four Points off the Kilpatrick turnpike, North part of city, within the SPG system).  No bad news to report here; just underwhelming spaces.  Don't pay $200/ nt unless you absolutely need location; or unless you're dutifully staying on your company to keep earning the starpoints!This location is walking distance of downtown and the famous bricktown. Great location.The staff is poised and gives an air of a high end hotel. The concierge is helpful and friendly.The location of the computers for guest use is a bit awkward, right in the middle of the lobby, but it's free internet, so who's complaining?The rooms are nice. The bar is decent. All in all for OKC, good spot.So the good things about this hotel are REALLY good - like the customer service. I very recently made Starwood Gold Preferred and this was my first dalliance with premier perks such as a room upgrade, 4pm check-out and a free gift (extra Starwood points, a complimentary cocktail or free wi-fi). Because this particular property is upgrading all Gold members to the Platinum tier as a promotion during the month of May, I received the full monty - a sweet room plus complimentary access to the top shelf amenities on literally, the top floor (aka the Sheraton Club Level replete with a private lounge, free appetizers during happy hour, gratis drinks and a legit complimentary breakfast, too).Yes, I'll say it so you don't have to - I make a fantastic travel partner!The hotel itself is well-priced, clean, moderately large, simply appointed yet reasonably up-to-date (though I wouldn't say modern) and situated in a very accessible part of downtown, if it wasn't for all the crazy construction going on. But, not their fault and a solid mobile GPS app should get you there without a major meltdown. Also super: the bar rocks it 'til 1:30am and a limited room service menu runs through the 2am hour. Not too shabby!Now, for the not so good: Within minutes of entering my room around 4pm, I was stopped dead in my tracks as I organized my belongings. What the hell is that? Eeeks, the dude next door must be watching porn with the volume maxed out. Then the sounds intensified and I could only think they must be FILMING a porn complete with outrageously fake sound effects. Oh no no no, friends - the walls are just this thin and not equipped to deal with anything louder than mumblings of sweet nothings, I deduced, while fearing our shared wall would tragically tumble down. While I'm not advocating that vacationing couples should be denied the novelty of hotel room sex, the Sheraton needs to figure this situation out so it's pleasant for participating and non-participating parties alike. And judging by similar observations noted in preceding reviews, I don't have especially sensitive ears. Speaking of, I'm now back hours later and it sounds like the lady lover is coughing from inside my room. Nooo, not round two!Ear plugs: IN. Good night?This hotel was great for our business conference. They have multiple meeting rooms on the 2nd floor and a restaurant by the hotel lobby. However, the hotel leaves a bit to be desired. You have to pay for the internet in your room, unless you sign up for the hotel's reward program. Although the program is free, it's a bit of a hassle. There were several stains on the carpet in my room, which I found to be a little disconcerting and gross. The bathroom is tiny and a bit difficult to maneuver around in, even for one person. I stayed at the hotel for 4 days and every afternoon, when I returned to my room after housekeeping had been there, my room was set up differently. There were 2 towels one day, 3 the next; no soap on the first day, one the second and 3 the third (all new). I would not book this hotel for a personal stay as I'd rather stay at a Hampton or Hilton. But overall it wasn't the worst hotel experience I've had.My friend and I checked in at 1730 and one of our rooms was still not ready.  The A/C would only work on high and the room was still warm.  I called guest services and they sent a guy up but he did not fix the problem.  The bartenders are very friendly but have no clue how to make a drink.  Food from the restaurant is above average.  There are many better hotels in OKC in this price range.Hmmm...where to start. First off, I got a great rate for this place so I'm not in any way complaining about the price. I'm going to complain about a few other things. I'm not much of a complainer, but the circumstances of my stay here warrant some complaints. The room physically was fine, somewhat dated but very clean. The rest of the stay was pretty miserable. I want to give this place 2 1/2 but I can't really justify a 3-star,I was driving from Chicago to LA. My first leg was a 12 hour drive from CHI to OKC.After 12 boring hours of driving through the midwest I arrive at the Sheraton. The place is packed and it's a Wednesday night. But it's not packed with the usual hotel patrons, its packed with adolescent and pre-teen kids. Apparently there was a Texas church retreat at the convention center the next day, the hotel was a mad house.I checked in relatively easy but I did have to pay for parking (I think $7 or something).I asked the hotel clerk if I was staying on a floor with the convention people...he told me that I was on a separate floor because these kids were causing a ruckus. Long story short, the entire hotel was peppered with these convention kids and they were not being very quiet into the wee hours of the night. The walls were paper thin and when 15 kids were running up and down the halls of the floor at 1am (I had to wake up at 7am to start the next leg) a call to security had to be made. They calmed things down for a minute. Now I've stayed in many many hotels in my life, and this is the first time I've ever felt the need to call security. But it was clear the hotel held no regard for their guests by not putting the convention folks on specific floors. I'm not sure how I fell asleep, maybe it was the entire bottle of cabarnet I polished off that was paid in advance unbeknownst to me with a credit card over the phone as a surprise by a very very special woman back in Chicago. But it only took her 3 calls and my 2 calls to the concierge to track it down as she was very upset when she called me and asked if I was enjoying the wine. "Wine? What wine!"Where's Jesus when you need him?
review_content_40: I don't have much reason to visit Oklahoma City.  Actually I've only been once, but this is where I stayed.  It's right by the arena and walking distance to a few restaurants.  Rooms are okay, lobby bar is okay.  Overall I'd say not bad.Not good. I have stayed here 3 times now on a weekend getaway because if you input 4-5 star in HOTWIRE (which rocks in my opinion) you will always get the Sheraton. The other hotels that are worth anything do not participate in Hotwire, just found that out. In any case the only good thing is you do get a great rate when using hotwire, enough about Hotwire. Not going to do that anymore. This place stinks. really, stinks like smelly stinky. Its old and needs total renovation. the staff is rude, rude. No amenities dirty rooms. Thin walls, bad food. Just really a waste. Go to the Skirvin, or Renaissance. If you dont just have to be downtown go to the Cambria. the Cambria is the best! There are also other places by the Airport that blow the Sheraton away. Dont waste your money here.This Sheraton was the home base for my festive night in OKC.  I got there after driving in from Dallas in my convertible...I was covered in sunscreen, wearing a hat over my sweaty hair, and just looking pretty hobo-ish.  Not a problem - the lady at the desk took my information and immediately got me into a room even though it was before check in time and didn't even give me the look up and down like I should probably be staying at a roadside motel!  Very nice.Room was nice but pretty basic.  Shower had the round rod so that you have more room to move around in there.  Beds were comfy.  TV was big.  Coffee maker with Starbucks coffee.  Oh and their hairdryer was greatness - full size, not one of those little baby ones.In the lobby they have a lounge area with a full bar and a restaurant plus a huge office center with a bunch of computers for your surfing and working pleasure.Best thing about this hotel is that it is conveniently located.  It is just a couple blocks walk to Bricktown for your drinking and eating needs and also a couple of blocks away from the OKC National Memorial.  Good home base for a fun time in OKC!Pros - Nicely appointed. Rooms are clean, reasonably sized with decent furnishings. Staff had great attitudes and over nice customer service. Room service menu has great variety and late night service. Restaurant and bar were good, too. Easy to access business center with free internet. Conveniently located. Oh, and the warm chocolate chip cookies and bottled water every afternoon weren't too bad either.Cons - Currently there is nearby road and construction work going on that makes it less than easy access and kind of a visual mess. But the BIGGEST PROBLEM is that all the walls are paper thin - could hear every single word of my neighbor's 3am conversation with the lover who was telling her that he was not leaving his wife for her...lots of sobbing and screaming, but I could hear even the low tense conversation leading up to that. After two nights of disruption, I had to request that the front desk address the problem, which they did.All in all, a nice place to stay.Lobby area is nice and modern. Staff was relatively efficient. The rooms however are dated and worn. The carpeting was dirty and matted. Nightstand was covered in some sort of dried liquid (icky!). Bathroom tub and floor were worn and shabby looking. Room was rather small and felt crowded by the two beds, desk, chairs, etc. The TV was a nice flat screen BUT it was only receiving a analog signal (terrible picture).  The TV remote was caked with filth. I used a alcohol wipe to clean it and it was gross after I wiped off the remote. Generally not the cleanest of rooms. I would have expected more from this property at this location.Room and AC system was deadly quiet! Slept like a baby. Free water for SPG guests and fast Internet. Breakfast staff was slower than the Dallas cowboys defensive line but this review is about the hotel, not the over priced, under serviced restaurant.I debated 2 or 3 stars for this hotel because the staff deserve some credit - they're very attentive and always helpful.Unfortunately, the rooms leave something to be desired. A lot of somethings.I've stayed here at least half a dozen times in the last 6 months.I'll start with some pros:- It's an SPG property and the only one in the downtown area. For a points lover like me, this is important.- The beds are decent (not great - kind of lumpy, actually)- The staff- The gym is large and has decent equipment with TVsNow the cons:- Bathrooms are WAY outdated. Not only that, but you can't move around in the bathroom without shutting the door. Also, the ceilings in most bathrooms that I've seen need major repairs.- There are crickets  EVERYWHERE. It's DISGUSTING. They're all over the gym even though I've repeatedly mentioned that the gym needs to be cleaned. Tonight I found 2 of them in my bathroom (and lucky me, one just went behind the bed). THAT IS UNACCEPTABLE. I am on the 15th floor, please tell me how they got here??- Carpets are dingy and gross- Food in the lounge sucks - I keep finding expired yogurt in the mornings, which no one but me (staff wise) seems to find troublesoon (example - today I found a yogurt that expired on 8/16. It's the 28th. Wrong.)- BUGS!!!- There are no long mirrors in any of the rooms. I don't get it. Who wants / needs to look at just their top half? That's more an annoyance than anything, but it is annoying.- The TVs have horrible color and NBC doesn't come in well.- There's a scary "ballroom" area off of the lobby that I walk through to get across to another downtown hotel... it is dark, scary and I've heard people say that they've seen people sleeping in there.Need I go on?Unless you're an SPG die hard like me, I recommend NOT staying here. Trust me, if it weren't for the points... I could CERTAINLY do without the crickets. Bluch!Also, SPG, if you're listening, you may want to consider taking this hotel off of your list until it gets a face lift... it is gross.Very nice staff, and a modern, efficient lobby. The room was a little small, but not too much so. Very comfortable, but the chair is not placed so one can watch the telly. This always annoys me, as I don't want to lie in bed to watch. The bathroom was also a bit small, but the room was modern and clean. Let me tell what I really love about this hotel, and I'd really give them 4.5 stars based on this alone. I noticed while on the elevator, that they have a 13th floor! Now, of course, every building with more than 12 has a 13th, but they skip it and label it as 14; an old superstition that is well past it's time and quite silly. So thank you, Sheraton, for actually having a 13th floor! And note to the concierge: The Medicine Cabinet is in no way similar to an Eckard's Drugs. Please don't send me there again! Offer to take me on the van, and earn that last star!Parking garage is confusing and $10 a day is ridiculous. There is no free wi-fi in the rooms because they have a business center downstairs but that is just not convenient to me.  Who wants to get presentable to go downstairs just to use the internet ?  The TV is very confusing and has lots of options for everything except TV. It was too difficult to get the remote to simply find regular channels to watch. We were on the 6th floor and could hear everything above and below us in the mornings and at night. The bathroom was ridiculously small. You open the door and strike the knees of the person sitting on the toilet ! Even with the curved shower curtain rod, the shower felt cramped. The pluses were the convenient location to the Cox Center and walking distance to the Bricktown Entertainment District.This is pretty much a 3 star hotel. I think it was renovated fairly recently, so the rooms looked pretty nice, but there were a lot of small details missing that keep it from getting a higher rating. Such as. .  .The shower sucked. It took a long time to get the temp right (and by 'right' I mean, not boiling or freezing) and the pressure was terrible. But hey, I'm not expecting a waterfall shower head or a soaking tub. It got me clean, that's what matters. Plus one for the bliss shower products- I tried to swipe a few from the carts in the hall but the housekeepers were always looking.The TV was a nice looking flat screen, but the signal was. . . analog? Is that even possible? Isn't all TV supposed to be digital now? I'm not sure what it was, but the reception was terrible. I don't need HD ( I don't even have HD at home) but a non-fuzzy TV would have been nice.The bed was suuuuper comfy but the whatever kind of mattress pad it had kept bunching up, pulling the fitted sheet with it. Kind of annoying.I suppose the location is good- within walking distance of Bricktown and the Murrah memorial (which is really worth seeing), honestly there doesn't seem to be a lot going on in OKC. . . The nearby Skirvin is nicer but more expensive, and apparently haunted. So while the Sheraton may not be 5 star, at least I didn't get molested in the shower.This hotel is not worth the price. I went to the hotel for a business trip and although I did not have to pay out of pocket for the hotel, I still think it was a rip off for my company.My coworker and I missed our connection to Oklahoma City on Monday. We called the hotel and told them that instead of staying Monday and Tuesday night, we would be staying Tuesday and Wednesday night. The person we spoke to said it was no problem and that they would change the reservation to Tuesday and Wednesday. When we got there, the VERY rude manager told us whoever we spoke to was wrong and that they would charge us for all 3 nights. When we missed our flight, we were fully expecting to pay for all 3 nights but I HATE when I get different information from different people. Don't tell me one thing one day and another the next.The breakfast buffet for $15.99 was not worth it AT ALL. It had fresh fruit (which was not fresh at all), omelets station, waffle station, bacon, eggs, fresh toast, and some other items. But they think they can charge this high price because there is NOTHING around there besides other hotel restaurants. My hotel information book (which is in every room) said that they will provide robes and slippers if requested. When I asked them about this, they said that they never had this and I could go to the hotel next door because they have a huge gift shop. If you don't have something in your hotel, you need to update your information that you provide to your guest. They have a hotel pool but it was closed when I went there.... in the middle of May. Also - my hotel key didn't work after I came back from dinner. I went to the front desk, the lady redid the keycode (or whatever it is they do) on the key and it still didn't work when I went back upstairs. When I went back down, she told me to stop holding the key to my phone because it was desensitizing the magnet. 1st - If your keycards are THAT sensitive, you should say something to begin with. 2nd - After the 1st time it didn't work, someone should of gone with me to my room to try the key. 3rd - The key didn't work the 2nd time either after I kept it FAR away from my phone. My coworker and I had adjoining rooms and she just let me in because I didn't want to deal with the lazy chick at the front desk.There is also NOTHING around the hotel. It was a 10 minute walk to any good restaurants. There was also no entertainment around the place. The only place the bellboy could tell me about was a bowling alley and a movie theater. Really? I agree that the walls are paper thin. I could hear the people next door taking a shower and their tv.If I end up at Oklahoma City again, I would try another hotel.I had never been to Oklahoma and we came from California to attend Bedlam (for non football fans ~ Oklahoma vs Ok State).  I really enjoyed OKC ~ Bricktown, botanical gardens, several museums ~ and the hotel was nicely located for all the things we wanted to do including walking to dinner.  However, it was simply old and run down. The staff was fine and I didn't find it to be dirty, so we had a nice enough stay and it worked fine for us.  I would even stay there again in the right situation, however I was disappointed and there are several hotels right in the area, so I would try the others first.  I'm simply writing this review because I wanted more from the hotel and I'm sure many of you will too.It's a generally nice hotel. The walls are paper thin. You could here when the room next door flushed and turned on the shower. The worst was when we could hear the guests next door having sex.  Like I said it's nice, but not great. We won't be backThis place seems to be undergoing renovations. I didn't hear any noises in the hallway but that may be due to the fact that they weren't doing any sort of work on my floor.The lobby looks nice. It is decorated in warm tones and doesn't have glaring artificial lighting. The front desk staff was friendly and allowed me to check-in a few hours early. I ordered my room on Priceline yet they were still willing to try and accommodate my request for two double beds. I would have had to check-in later but I am grateful that the request on record and were willing to help me. The room itself is nice. It's spacious (perhaps I'm comparing it to an NY hotel but still), the furniture is your basic dark wood, with blue comforters and normal hotel colors. They have Bliss products which smell wonderful. The bed is super comfortable and I looked forward to sleeping in that thing every night.I ordered room service. The wings were meh but the sweet potato fries were a nice touch. They're not as crispy as regular fries but full of flavor. You are a short walk from an area called Bricktown where there are several bars, restaurants, and a movie theater. I didn't get to try the food here but from the looks of the people and the decor in various places it looks like it could be a fun area.Everyone I talked to at this hotel was super friendly and accommodating. They are truly what makes this a nice hotel. Now all they need to do is catch up on some minor repair work and finish the construction.The only downside was the shower curtain. it was obviously time to change or wash that thing. It's some sort of cloth material and they need to be washed frequently in order to prevent mildew.The A/C unit was louder than I'd like. I know they're not all whisper quiet but in comparison to the quiet in the hall and the city itself it can be distracting if you're a light sleeper.Mediocre!!! They want to look expensive with NOTHING substantial.I had to change room because you could hear the neighbors. The food at the restaurant was mediocre not to be mean, and you have to park your car at a public place next door for $10/day. Also, if you want the internet in your room, its nearly $10 too. LOL. Those corporate Americans hotels SHOULD BE BOYCOTTED, period.We got a block of 12 rooms for our 20 year class reunion on July 31st. We thought they would all be together but we were all on different floors.When we got there we didn't want to do the Valet Parking so we parked ourselves in the hotel parking that they told us to park. We were suppose to get a pass that we figured out later for our parking. We never got this so we paid out $7.00.When we got to our room the bathroom had a spray of some weird stuff on the wall and the bathroom smelled of urine. Tiny bathroom.My BF went to the ice-machine to get some ice and it was broken. It was so hot and I called to ask them to fix it and they never did. So we had one hot bottled water for the two of us. They put us by the elevator so we had to listen to the elevator going up and down all night like we were on top of a subway. Pops in the machine were two dollars. I just wasn't impressed. Marriott the next time for sure.I think we got the Hotwire rm: end of hall and 2 double beds and it said HTW on our key slip. $10/day for parking and no free wi-fi which was terribly disappointing. Breakfast at Aria Grill was okay- we chose the buffet which was best deal, $15/head incl coffee and juice. Large flat screen TV with bad picture quality. Beds nice and firm, not overly firm, with 10 pillows each. Location is okay. Would've rather stayed at Hampton Inn and Suites which is much closer to Bricktown restaurants/bars/canal. Also Hampton had great inside pool with fountain which was visible from street and Sheraton did not have an inside pool, only outside pool which was still covered on June 5  ?? Recommended only for business folks whose company is paying for rm service, parking, and rm.Not a bad spot ... Easy access to Bricktown.  You can get great deals on this place on priceline!

review_content: We consider the Skirvin our "home away from home" and visit several times a year. The hotel is gorgeous and the service impeccable. Amy Nelms in the Red Piano Lounge is a true professional and makes our time there so much fun. The food is really good, too. There are just two little things I'd like to mention. First, it would be so nice if the rooms had mini refrigerators. Or at the very least, offered real cream in the room instead of Coffee Mate for our morning coffee/tea. Second, we were disappointed this past weekend to discover that they now have different pillows. These are hard and uncomfortable. I much preferred the ones they had before. Is it possible to request down pillows? Finally, I absolutely love the scent when you walk in the place and would love to know what it is. P.S. We really miss the limo service. Mike was a real treasure.First note: this review is based on a holiday event hosted at The Skirvin. We did not stay in a room. The good: The hotel is decorated to the nines at Christmas time. Just walking around the lobby and the second level was worth the trip downtown. It was magical for my entire group, and I may take another trip this holiday season just for some nice photos of the family.The bad: The event my group and I attended was Breakfast With Santa. I have attended fun events like this at Disney World and in Las Vegas, so it is likely my expectations were much too high. - The reservation for the event is over priced (more on that later). - The buffet breakfast food was ok, but definitely not something I would be eager to try again. - While the atmosphere of the hotel was amazing, the ballroom itself left much to be desired. Considering it was a room full of children, it would have been nice for there to be some fun decorations for them to interact with. - The "cast" was a mix of pleasant and disappointing. The elves were the best, super friendly, sweet and entertaining. Everyone was nice, but it was obvious this wasn't a big gig to them (it wasn't on the same level as a Disney event). The organization seemed ok. Would have been nice for seating to have been assigned, especially for bigger parties, since there are limited seats per table. But things progressed timely. The ugly: - OK, maybe I am just a stickler, but gratuity traps really bother me. The price is $25 for adults and $16 for kids. However, when you arrive and prepay, they add in an additional gratuity! We ended up at 30 dollars a person, even with a few kids in our group! Why don't you just advertise it as 30 dollars a person and NOT add in these additional charges at time of payment. I just can't wrap my mind around the logic of that. I felt scammed, but I couldn't say "nevermind" for fear of unwanted charges. So, will I go back to The Skirvin? Probably. Will my family attend this event again next year? Definitely not.I recently got married and decided to spend our wedding night at the Skirvin. What sounded like a great idea at first was all down shortly after arriving. Our group of about 30 arrived around 10pm to the Skirvin and visited the red piano lounge. Asides our group there was a mere 2-4 other patrons so clearly we greatly contributing to the bars profit on what would of been a slow night. We were easily contributing in excess of $1000 in just alcohol alone.After glancing at a menu which says food as served till midnight we were quickly told they are closing the kitchen down and would not do anymore orders for the 20 people(including my bride in her wedding dress) we were denied with not much worry and told we can speak to hotel management if we had a problem with it. After making our rounds through various hotel staff members only to be dismissed to the next person and on to the next person. Several members of our party had to UBER elsewhere for food which is no easy task from the downtown area. And then had to UBER back. It became clear that the employees were more eager to get home vs. make more money for their company and accommodate the bride and the wedding party. Copies of their menu clearly state food is served until midnight and can be found here: skirvinhilton.com/pdf-sk...After all this we gave up and went to our room feeling much like the maid that Bill Skirivin kept captive on the 10th floor who jumped out of the window since we had already paid for our room prior to arriving. The icing on the cake was finding bugs in our bed the next morning. I would avoid this hotel at all costs if it is a special occasion.Did you hear about the two bed bugs who met in the mattress? They got married in the spring.If Kyrie is spending his night there brawling bed bugs...than i'm not going back.Really cool hotel. Old school charm with modern touches. Lobby was breathtaking with red curtains, piano bar, chandeliers. Very clean. Room had a wonderful view and lots of windows. Comfortable bed. Overpriced. But our experience was great. And we loved our stay.My wife just wrote a review but I had to add my two cents, as well. We just had our daughter's wedding reception at the Skirvin and it was outstanding!Molly and the staff catered to our every need and delivered as we had hoped! All of the bride and grooms friends have already dubbed the event "the best reception ever!" Highly recommend the hotel and especially Molly!Have stayed at the Skirvin several times, but I hadn't stayed there for a few years until this week. It's still a top notch hotel, and probably my favorite one in Oklahoma City. On my most recent stay, I arrived pretty early, around 9:00 on a Friday. I was able to check in and immediately go up to my room, so that was nice. The employees at the front desk were very friendly.I'm reluctant to call a hotel owned by Hilton a "boutique," but the Skirvin really is. It's older, and I have been staying here when the elevators aren't working. So, that can be annoying, but old buildings have character to them that I like. The bed is comfortable, but the bathroom is on the smaller side. The last room I had included a tub/shower combo that was average size. There is free wireless internet. There are a couple of chairs in the rooms which are comfortable but make the place feel more cramped than it is. No minibar that I saw, but they give you a couple of Aquafinas. Valet parking is $12 a day or $26 overnight. The guys are pretty prompt and you can call down if you need your car and they'll have it waiting. If you don't want to pay for parking, I frankly don't know a free place to park near the Skirvin. It would be blocks away though, because all of the garages and lots near downtown charge. So, I'd take advantage of the valet.There is a great bar downstairs, the Red Piano. Additionally, the restaurant at the hotel is the Park Avenue Grill. They've got a breakfast buffet and 24 hour room service, which is not the norm in Oklahoma. I've only had breakfast at the restaurant, but it was good. The lobby is comfortable and nicely appointed. It's not trendy, but it also doesn't feel like you're in a 100 year old building (or however old the Skirvin is).Everyone I encountered was very friendly and frequently asking what they could do for me. I'll absolutely stay here again.My husband and I stayed here for our wedding night. It was a gift to us and was prepaid, but as is customary, they asked for us to provide a card for incidentals upon check-in. The entire room was charged to us even though it had been paid for by our friends. We also asked that a refrigerator be sent to our room as this was done for other guests of the wedding staying at the Skirvin. We never received it. Our champagne wasn't chilled, which was also to be part of the "romance package." For one of the most expensive hotels in Oklahoma City, it was pretty terrible customer service. My mom stayed at the Colcord that evening. I would recommend that over the Skirvin ten times over. Very disappointed.Called ahead to ask for a decent room with a view and on a higher floor, the girl asked if I booked on Hotwire and I said yes...because why would anybody pay full price for something ever, if you had the chance to not pay full price? It was only $20/night off and I wish I had booked regularly to avoid the rudeness. She asked me to hold on, came back and said 'uuhhh there aren't any good rooms left, but we put you in the best possible'. Mind you, this was barely after check-in on a Thursday night (the hotel was dead when we got there). Checked in, went up to the room and it was almost level to the upper level of the parking garage with a huge spotlight shining into the room. We went back downstairs and said, never mind, just give us any room that doesn't overlook the parking garage, even an interior room. They got the 'you eat ass face' and gave us new keys without saying a single word. Not only did this room have a nice view and was a higher level, it was connected to the presidential suite. It was a bigger and better room. Way to discriminate against Hotwire users, when you have a deal. I used to work in a 4 star hotel in downtown Dallas and this is not the way you treat anybody. The rooms are very run down, in general. The carpets are dingy and always feel damp. The beds are uncomfortable. There was no mini fridge. There was a long, curly pube on the ground in the bathroom. This is all insane considering 3 star hotels in smaller cities right next to OKC (Norman to be exact) are 10 times nicer. I have used hotwire for 4 star hotels in OKC previously but never had the bad luck to get the Skirvin. I will not be booking through HW again for OKC because of the risk of us getting this nasty hotel again.Despite the odd name (Skirvin being entirely too close to scurvy and skeevy) this hotel was a beautiful place to stay. Built in the early 1900s, it's been through many incarnations, resurrections and devastation. Now it's a grand hotel with a bordello like feel, reminiscent of the old west (but without the shady characters.) It's also one of America's most haunted hotels. Effie, the ghost, apparently propositions men in the bathroom of room 1015. Guess which room we were in? Yep. 1015. Though we didn't hear her dulcet tones, the hot water mysteriously stopped working the day of check out. Effie or bad plumbing? We preferred the ghost story.Our beds were comfortable, the bathroom was huge, the room was oddly shaped but good enough for 3 people to roam around in without incident. The piano lounge downstairs is a little pricey drink-wise but then it's a hotel bar and a classic hotel bar at that. A great and affordable group hotel in the center of downtown OKC.It was a great hotel, very old and historic but not what I think of what I book at Hilton.com. Several people told me it was haunted and it just felt awkward.Service was great, sleep was good and room service was awesome!Lost those other 2 starts due to the non Hilton like Hotel that's haunted and looks too old!It needs some TLC and a major renovation!I've never seen such a beautiful and historic place as I saw at this hotel. Is the hotel haunted though? I asked and you'll have to ask when you check in too!This hotel is beautiful and so worth the place to stay in Oklahoma City. The rooms are spacious.Valet parking is affordable and worth it, because self parking is literally 3 blocks away.My boyfriend and I were really excited to spend our anniversary here this past weekend but were sadly disappointed... He was insistent on us staying somewhere nice since I found out later that he was planning on proposing, which made me feel really bad for choosing this place... As we pulled in we waited for the valet to get to our car for at least 15 minutes even though there was only one car they were helping in front of us. I believe that if we are paying $26/day for the "service and convenience" of a valet they should at least be kind and attempt to expedite the process of checking in a car. This is also the first 4 star hotel that I stayed at with no sort of shuttle service. The front desk workers were the least accommodating I have ever worked with. Our room had a horrible view of the parking structure and even though we knew that they had quite a few rooms available they refused to check before telling us that there was nothing they could do. The staff acted as if they couldn't be bothered whenever we asked simple questions such as the hours of the pool and when we asked if it was possible for us to do a late checkout did not even bother to check the computer but rather rudely brushed us off. For the price of a 4 star hotel and staff quality and amenities of a 1 or 2 star hotel will we definitely opt to stay elsewhere the next time we are in the city. Even being used to staying at 4 star hotels in Hawaii and California I would choose the Hampton inn over this place any day.The main reason for a 4-star rating is the extreme niceness of all the hotel employees I dealt with during my recent stay. Seriously, I don't think I've ever been treated better anywhere in my life!The hotel itself was pretty nice, and in general I was very pleased with it (a new shower cap was provided by housekeeping every day without having to ask for one - HAPPY DANCE!!), but there are a couple of things that would have made it even better - such as a mini-refrigerator in every room, and more vegan options in the hotel restaurant's menu for breakfast, lunch and dinner. There weren't really any vegan options to speak of (a banana or an apple doesn't really count as a meal, by the way), but some that could be made vegan, if you left out a number of non-vegan ingredients. More and more people are choosing the vegan lifestyle, and any restaurant that accommodates us with a decent number of tasty and healthy vegan options will earn our loyalty and our recommendation. I do wish more restaurants would wake up to this fact. We're not going away - in fact, our numbers are ever-increasing - and we need to eat, too. To leave us out of the equation as if we don't count is to treat us like second-class citizens. Come on now, we deserve better than that! Perhaps I shouldn't dwell so much on that point, as if it makes them different from other hotels - it doesn't. The point is, this hotel is so much better on so many levels than other hotels I've stayed in, so I expect better from them. If they would make a significant effort to improve in this area, the Skirvin Hilton would be just about perfect!What a grand hotel! In for a national CFS meeting. Guess my expectations were fairly low so what a pleasant surprise this hotel was. The lobby and check-in were a breeze with helpful staff, great bellman, accommodating yet low key personnel. The rooms were spacious, updated and well maintained. The dining room was elegant and servers stayed in the background but were at your table the moment you needed them. The meeting rooms were great and wifi everywhere with no problem when over a hundred of us signed on at the same time. The ballroom was absolutely spectacular with beautiful chandeliers and great acoustics. A lot of history, hauntings and hysterical stories that are shared by staff if you ask. It is located in the center of town within walking distance to many places you want to visit.Would recommend this hotel for anyone staying in OKC whether for work or play!I travel to Oklahoma City for work and stay at this hotel almost every week (except when it's sold out, which is often). The hotel is beautiful and historic and definitely has an old timey but modernized look and feel too, having been renovated within the last decade after having been abandoned for many years. The rooms are spacious with beautiful fixtures and luxurious bathrooms. The piano bar on the first floor adds a nice ambiance to the location. The other amenities like the fitness center are quite nice as well and it conveniently connects to the city's underground tunnels, which I can luckily take to the office I work at when it's very cold.I've heard and read of its history as a haunted hotel and have been accordingly receptive to any strange goings-on. I can honestly report that I haven't experienced anything strange in the slightest. The hallways are spacious and often empty which gives a somewhat creepy "The Shining" hotel feel, but otherwise, the hotel feels quite normal. No strange sounds, mysteriously moving objects, or ghostly apparitions joining me in the shower. Just a lovely old hotel.Highly recommended for your next stay in OKC!This is definitely my home away from home. In entering the building you walk back in time into an era where class and elegance were abundant. The desk staff are warm and courteous and anxious to help. Once arriving in your room, you cannot help but to feel right at home. When you climb into bed you'll find that the bed actually embraces you. Or could that be the token ghost? The continental breakfast is superb, as everything that comes out of the Park Avenue Grill usually is. I have stayed many, many times and have yet to find something to complain about. This hotel comes highly suggested!This is one of the best Hilton Hotels in The United States. Just completed a two day speaking program at this location. The lobby is wonderful and the bar is a relaxing place at night. The hotel is reportedly haunted with the cab driver trying to scare me on my ride in from the airport - he gave up when he discovered I was laughing at him. My room was wonderful clean, quiet and the maids spoke English. I could have moved into this hotel to live for a long time. The staff is friendly professional and willing to help you at anytime with room service available 24/7. You are located just a few minutes walk from Bricktown and museums this hotel gets my top rating!Such a magnificent hotel! The architecture and design of the building is simply breathtaking. Such incredible detail and integrity was involved in the restoration process. Every aspect of our stay was simply superb. Our rotunda suite was pristine and every aspect of cleanliness was adhered to fully. The furnishings are reminiscent of the era and the lobby is incredibly glamorous! The hallways and elevators are grand!!! Room service for breakfast was impeccable. We will definitely return when visiting the area!!!
review_content_20: This hotel is by far the best Hilton I've had the pleasure to stay at. It made a great stopover with easy access to bricktown. The rooms have new but locally elegant furniture rather than the same old hilton wares. The Lobby is beautiful and the staff are friendly and want to Help.Came here for an Xmas party, I did not stay the night..  Visually, the hotel is amazing! Definitely one of the nicer ones in Bricktown. I give it 3 stars because I was not impressed with their service or food.I love the Skirvin!  Just like the proverbial Phoenix rising from the ashes this historic hotel has gone from empty and barren when I was a kid to one of my favorite hotels in the country.  The only comparable hotel I've found on par with the Skirvin for historic value, luxury and modern amenities is the Hilton Presidential in Kansas City although the Skirvin trumps it. On average I stay at the Skirvin around 8-12 times a year.  Always for pleasure - for a random in-town vacation or on nights when I'm out late and rates are reasonable and for my now five year tradition of staying several days over New Year's.  As a cultural refugee living 30 miles away in Shawnee because of my business I have to stay at hotels frequently when I'm going out on the town.  Oh, I have plenty of friends in the area that would take me in but I'm not the stay on the couch kind of guy anymore so I tour all the hotels in OKC but will jump at the chance to stay at the Skirvin anytime it presents itself.  Every room is exceptionally appointed, from the suites to the regular rooms.  You really can't go wrong with any selection.  The suites are located on the front of the hotel in the rounded turrets of the building on each floor.  They are enormous for a hotel of this age but unfortunately missing a tub, although the bathroom is huge and the shower is great.  Most suites come standard with both but that's a first world complaint of the highest order. The hotel has been wonderfully renovated yet still maintains its turn of the century and mid century charm and architecture.  There are some wonderful art deco aspects to the hotel from the lobby to the beautiful the tile mural in the restaurant.  You feel as if you have stepped back in time when you are in this hotel - just with flat screen TVs and beds from the future!  Ahh the beds.  I wish I knew just exactly what brand these beds were as I'd have one delivered directly to my house.  They are amazingly comfortable.  Some hotel chains, like the W for instance, basically allow you to order everything in the room if you should so desire including the bed and bedding - if Hilton offered this at the Skirvin I would do it! The scent of the Skirvin is also majestic.  I started noticing the signature scents of hotels several years ago - mainly at places like the W, which can be overbearing.  The Skirvin's signature scent they pipe in is subtle yet gets me on some kind of emotional level.  Yeah I know, I sound like a maudlin fool.  They say scent is our most powerful sense and I believe it as I look forward to basking in its essence with every stay. Their signature scent is a trade secret so don't bother asking as I've been rebuffed every time I've asked.  The basement gym is fantastic.  Its not too large but has enough weights and cardio equipment to get the job done and is conveniently located next to their hot tub and smallish pool.  They say the Skirvin is haunted and while I don't believe in such nonsense I've been down in the pool by myself a few times and without anyone else around it is kind of unsettling.  And of course, the infamous stories you hear about ghostly crying babies and Effie the maid who committed suicide by jumping out a window are just that - stories and I've never once in my many stays encountered any paranormal activity.  Supposedly Effie will appear nude and proposition men in the shower but nary a naked succubus have I seen.  Nevertheless it makes for good stories and adds to the "history" of this legendary hotel.  The only minus - and this is a huge one - is the abomination of a restaurant that is the cornerstone of their property - the Park Avenue Grill.  I so want to like this place and have been here often but I've always left disappointed.  They have been through several supposedly high profile chefs since I started frequenting this hotel and I try to give them the benefit of the doubt but it's just bad, really really bad  - and overpriced!  You would think a world class hotel like the Skirvin would have a world class restaurant, but it is just not to be - yet!  Another downside is their valet parking which suddenly shot up from $20 to $27 within a two year period.  I understand the enormous costs associated with the upkeep of this hotel but be careful the Skirvin will nickle and dime you at every chance it gets.Forget about the rest, the Skirvin is the best. The Hilton Skirvin hotel is not only the best hotel in OKC it's one of the best Hilton hotels in the world.  The rich history of this hotel and its hauntings, yep, hauntings, makes it stand on it's own as one of the most beautiful, legendary,  unique, haunted hotels ever. Legend has it that back in the day Mr. William Balser "Bill" Skirvin had an affair with a young, beautiful, african american maid named Effie.  Reportedly Mr. Skirvin knocked her up, then locked her up, in a suite on the 10th floor (originally the top floor) of the hotel to avoid scandal as he was a married man. Mr. Skirvin still would not let her go free even after she gave birth thus driving her completely mad/crazy being locked up for so long. So, one day she just snapped, took her baby and jumped out the window killing herself and their love child. Over the years its been commonplace that guests again & again complain about not being able to sleep, due to the incessant sounds of a child crying. According to some, a nude Effie is known to appear to male hotel guests while showering, and her voice can be heard propositioning them. One dude even reports being fondled by her as another claims he was sexually assaulted!!! Many staff members have reported everything from strange noises to things moving by themselves.In January of 2010, the New York Knicks basketball team told the New York Daily News they were unable to sleep the night before a game with the Oklahoma City Thunder. "I definitely believe there are ghosts in that hotel," said center Eddy Curry. Forward Jared Jeffries added, "The place is haunted. It's scary."I have been stayin at the skirvin on and off for over a month now as my hubby & I recently relocated to OKC.  It is truly a beautiful hotel there is no doubt about that. The first week we were there we were on the 10th floor.   My hubby & I had the craziest dreams ever while staying there.  At that time, I did not know of the stories of Effie. One night we were in our room on the 10th floor & I woke up around 4am from a nightmare about my mothers recent tragic passing.  I swore I saw this shadow of a woman in the dark float across the room and out the window, but I thought it was my imagination, as I had several drinks at the Red Piano Bar in the lobby earlier that night.  Someone then told me in passing about Effie. That next week the dreams continued as we were on the 9th floor. One evening late I was looking out the window as I went to shut the curtains, I looked up at the 10th floor and saw a woman holding what appeared to be a baby in the window. I went and asked, the room was vacant.   The strange dreams continued for the entire months stay. We even checked into another hotel and the dreams stopped.  We would check back into the Skirvin as we both love the hotel and again crazy dreams. The pool in the basement is a bromine pool (salt water) The hot tub is as well. They keep the temp of the hot tub at 105. The gym is amazing. The beds are super comfy.  The linens are fantastic, the Peter Thomas Roth bath products are fantastic. All the rooms have terry robes. The rooms are around $250 a night, beautiful furniture, well appointed, fantastic service, from the front desk to the house keeping.  Even the pool guy was super cool as I spend a great deal of time in the pool, hot tub and gym. The Red Piano Bar in the lobby is amazing and all the servers were super friendly & professional. I had a beautifully cooked salmon Cesar salad at the bar several times.  It was all fantastic.  However, the room service has a 20% upcharge for room service and the valet parking is very expensive.  Better to eat downstairs and park yourself in the garage behind the hotel and walk back around it's only a half block. I do want to say thank you to the entire staff for making our stay a most pleasant one. "Thank you all, your hospitality is unrivaled. Your hotel is magnificent as well as your service. Our whole stay was flawless we both truly enjoyed it. Well done!" Every member of the staff was so kind & wonderful to us making it our home away from home while we searched for and moved into our city flat.  We very much enjoyed our stay. I absolutely love this hotel I would totally recommend it for its quality, service and fantastic amenities.  I will most def stay again in the future.  But, I will never, ever, again stay on the 10th floor.BEDBUGS! Recently stayed here this past weekend and attended a wedding. Will not be staying here again and definitely not recommending this hotel to anyone I know. We had a room with 2 double beds and one bed had bedbugs crawling all over it. When calling the frtont desk, they sent someone up to my room who agreed with me and said that this was a big problem. I didn't expect this at the Skirvin so something like this only tells me that the cleaning crew does not change the sheets and probably not wash them. If you choose to stay at this hotel, turn y our room upside down and check for anything crawling around! The pictures attached to my review don't even begin to show how many were crawling in the bed!My new hotel in Oklahoma City. Old school nice, kind of steely, wide hallways big rooms, well appointed, clean and quiet.  Great restaurant downstairs, and the piano lounge is a nice stop that can make the end of your work day a joy.  My choice for here.Last Saturday night, an old high school friend had a surprise party at the Skirvin Hotel. On the second floor, there were 3 hostesses that directed us to the banquet room. There was a wide selection of food: Alfredo penne pasta, green beans, carrots, meatballs, etc! The meatballs were to. die. for. Inside it was an open bar - the bartender, J (I'll refrain from using his full name), was incredibly sweet, attentive, and friendly. The entire staff was WONDERFUL - they surely deserve 5 stars!!I give 4 stars because I felt the food was taken too early. . .after all of the drinks from the open bar it would have been nice to have some food after. ;)Unsure of how the hotel service is if you grab a room, but the food, company, venue & employees made the night awesome!The debonair Skirvin is certainly a throwback to a different era with its ornate lobby fully decked with plush charm between its crazy high ceilings and huge, Alice in Wonderland-esque chairs. The staff was also wonderful, and the super soft bedding lulled me into one of the deepest slumbers I've had all month.However - the thread count of your sheets won't guarantee heavenly rest if the walls are built paper thin. I was up before 6am (1.5 hours before my alarm was set to go off) due to two different alarms going off within minutes of each other, down the hall from me. If you're a moderate-to heavy sleeper you'll fare just fine... but, you're straight out of luck if you're a lightweight in the zzzzs department. You can also hear people talking in their rooms/on the phone, though it isn't so creepy that you'll be able to understand them. Probably not the place you'd stay at for a romantic getaway... privacy is a good thing, no?Good night, guys - gotta catch up on some sleep!While I typically like to check out boutique hotels when exploring new cities, sometimes it's nice to stay at the well known chains because you know what you're getting. When we first booked the Hilton I expected good service, a clean spacious room and an adequate gym. I got all that and more during my 24 hours in Oklahoma City.I didn't spend very much time in my hotel room, but was easily able to catch up on some ZZZ's in their cozy bed. Fortunately, I didn't hear until the next day that the Skirvin is supposedly haunted cause that would have kept me from getting such a good night sleep. I woke up to no ghosts and ventured down to the basement to the gym filled with all sorts of cardio and weight equipment. And I had it all to myself.  You have to pay for wifi in their rooms, although they do offer complimentary wifi in the hotel lobby. The plush couches in the lobby became my office during my short stay.I wasn't thrilled with the location because there didn't seem to be many dining options within walking distance. My colleague and I enjoyed 2 meals at the restaurant at the hotel, but ventured out for a long walk in the cold for our 3rd meal in OKC.  I wouldn't hesitate to book the Skirvin again, but next time I would also look for a more centrally located hotel...or rent a car.The ghost tour at 10:30 is interesting.I was very happy with my unexpected stay the hotel had great serviceBeautiful hotel.... Paper thin walls.... This place was remodeled a few years ago & I must say the place is really nice...  But the should have put a little more into the walls.  Both nights I was woken up by the guests next door.  I let the hotel manager know after day 1, but nothing was done...  It was still far from my worst hotel stay & other than the noise, the place was great. I will be back.This is a beautiful old hotel that's been masterfully restored with a modern kick. If you can find a good rate, stay here! Valet parking is expensive, but there's a public garage adjacent that's only $6-7/day. Staying in downtown OKC is fun for a change. Try it when you're planning an evening at the Civic Center. We've done that several times. Have a late night drink in the red piano lounge, but try to ignore the out-of-tune red piano. It's there for color only.The sleeping rooms are big-city small but luxuriously appointed. Large meeting rooms on the 2nd floor are typical, and the ones on the top floor have lots of character. The banquet and A/V staff are fantastic! FAN-TASTIC, in case you didn't get that. If you're planning a conference or large event, they will make your guests happy.This was a great wedding location. The hotel staff did a great job and the Grand Ballroom was perfect for the reception. The food was good and the hotel room was perfect!  We enjoyed the breakfast buffet after our comfy night and a generous noon check-out. Great job Hilton!I stay here about once/month for work and every time I do, I'm reminded why I love this hotel so much. As I sit here enjoying my hotel room, I thought I'd update this review once more. I'm adding a star. Gorgeous. Inside and out. Such a great historic building downtown. The exterior, lobby and individual rooms are so classy and have just the right amount of "over the top" luxury chic.Best. Beds. Ever. I could sleep for 14 hours in these amazing beds. And I can't forget the comfy robe, one-cup coffee maker, great bath products, and soft towels. It's also walking distance to almost anywhere downtown and Bricktown, which I enjoy.It's worth every penny :)This is without a doubt my favorite hotel to stay in, anywhere.  I am a Hilton Diamond member (I stay in a ton of Hilton-brand hotels for business), and this one trumps all the rest.  In addition to being a historical location, the tasteful renovations to this property throughout the years give this place an 'old time' feel with modern amenities.  All finishes are absolutely top-end, and you really feel like are taken back in time (in a good way).As other users have stated, the location is downtown OKC- great for business travel or for personal travel (Bricktown is walkable, likewise with the OKC Memorial- a must).  From the minute you walk into the property, there is a grand feeling with chandeliers, rich cherry/mahogany wood everywhere, large floor to ceiling velvet curtains, a giant fire red grand piano, and lots of 'original' yet restored touches.  The mail drop is original to the property, and the walls are lined with historical photos and memoribilia from the hotel's past.  I'm not much a history guy, but the photos of royalty, presidents, and famous actors staying at the property are really pretty neat.The restaurant attached has an excellent breakfast buffet with omelet chef.  I get free vouchers to eat there due to my Hilton status (thankfully, because for 2 people its like $40 normally).  I've never had dinner at the restaurant, but I've heard positive reviews... like breakfast, I'll assume its pricey.I have stayed at this property I think 6 times and have had a standard room, a suite, and the presidential suite.  The standard room is as large or larger than a normal standard hotel room, and the bathrooms are very nice- has the granite counter, dark wood counter, and really cool tasteful wall paper.  The shower heads are large, and like all Hilton properties it has the curved shower rod.  The king beds are plush with excellent bedding.  All of the furniture in the rooms is new- I think from an 08' remodel.  Just about all rooms in the property have some view of downtown.The suite is really neat with a large red sofa in the TV room with great views of downtown.  There is a separate bedroom and bath area with similar excellent high-end finishes.  No expense spared by the interior decorator.  The presidential suite is huge.  I've only stayed in this unit once, but it encompasses 3 standard rooms.  The shower has 6 body sprayers on it, an overhead rainfall head and a standard shower head.  The mirror in the bathroom has a TV built-in.  The whirlpool tub is standard.  All of the other rooms are luxurious like the standard room and suite room.  Awesome.The staff has always been very friendly with me, and is usually pretty knowledgeable about the area- they'll provide dining recommendations etc upon request.  This place is highly recommended, and I'm certain I will stay there again in the future.  Room rates vary greatly- some time its $119/night, sometimes its $169/night for a standard room and higher.  I have no idea what the driver is for the rates.  If you use Hilton points, I think its 30,000 points/night.  Internet is free for Hilton Gold/Diamond members... not sure if you have to pay otherwise.We've spent numerous special occasions at the Skirvin. Bachelorette parties, Easter brunches, drinks with friends, and even our wedding reception.I fundamentally believe that the Skirvin offers the most service, amenities, and style than any other Oklahoma City event venue, Hotel, or hotspot.And you HAVE to check out the Red Piano bar. It's my favorite late-night drink spot.I've never been homesick for a hotel before.  Oh my goodness.  The minute we checked out, I was missing it already.It was love at first sight with the dark wood, intricate chandeliers, and luxurious red velvet curtains in the lobby.  We had been delayed arriving, but a quick call to the front desk en route was all it took to get everything squared away.  They pre-checked us in and had our keys waiting when we arrived.The doors to the elevators are gorgeous antiques -- take a moment to admire them.  This entire hotel has been around for almost a century, and it was renovated and reopened in 2007, but they simply restored rather than replaced, which means that this hotel is a beautiful mix of old-world charm and new-world accommodations.  (Let's talk about the heated, anti-fog bathroom mirrors.)  The hallways are simple yet elegant, and the rooms (even the basic ones!) are divine.  I slept better in that bed than I do at home.  No lie.There are a bajillion cable channels to choose from, but the wireless internet isn't free, which is part of what contributed to a 4-star rating rather than a 5-star rating.  Another tiny mark down for the cost of parking ($10 a day) -- but here's a BIG tip...if you're there on a weekend, the meters in front of the hotel (about 10 spots) are free.  So, we didn't have to pay for parking, but normally we would have.  Also, we only had to pay $25 per room, because I was traveling with a friend who works for Hilton.  That definitely helped me view this hotel more favorably.  If I had been paying the regular rate (I think $150?), I might not have been quite so over-the-moon.  Thus, only 4 stars instead of 5.  Still, though, it was close.A lovely, lovely spot if you ever find yourself traveling to Oklahoma City.  We were even traveling with the primary intention of visiting Norman, and the commute (20 minutes) wasn't too bad.Truly a nice hotel.  Classic charm and feel.  Not sure what the regular rate is since I was on the corporate plan but worth it.I was a little nervous staying in a older hotel.  Not because I was worried the hotel wasn't updated, but because of ghosts.  I think I would like Casper the Friendly Ghost if I met him.  But when I want to sleep, I want to sleep.  I'm happy to report there were no spirits in the hallway (just the liquor spirits in our room, ha ha ha).This hotel is a great hotel right in downtown Oklahoma City, within walking distance to Brickyard and other bars / restaurants.  You have to valet to park there, but that is pretty common in any downtown hotel.  The architecture was amazing.  Completely reminds me of older buildings that have since fell to the wrecking ball.  The lobby was very ornate.  Lots of dark wood and soaring ceilings.  Made me feel like I was one of the great Gatsbys.  The rooms were very modern and comfortable.  We had a corner room that overlooked a part of downtown.  Our room had a big TV and an iPod docking station.  If memory serves, I believe they have WiFi in the room.  However, I cannot remember if we had to pay for it.I highly recommend this hotel if you are staying in the downtown Oklahoma City area.The 411-------(Source: WSJ)Located at One Park Avenue, the 14-story, smoke-free hotel is comprised of three separate towers with 225 guest rooms, including 20 one-bedroom suites and one Presidential Suite. Hotel amenities include the signature Park Avenue Grill restaurant, which retains the Art Deco look of the hotel's former interior design, the Red Piano lounge, a fitness center, indoor swimming pool, business center, 18,500 square feet of meeting and pre-function space and a Hiltons HHonors lounge. History Lesson--------------The original Skirvin Hotel was Built by William Skirvin, who participated in the Oklahoma Land Run of 1889 and later made a fortune in land and oil. The Skirvin is near railroad depots and is an example of the grand hotels that prospered during the golden age of railroad travel.It is said that back in the day "If you were in the lobby of the Skirvin Hotel, whatever was going on in Oklahoma City would pass right in front of you."The recently re-opened Skirvin has a renewed luster, after being hidden away for almost 20 years as it sat boarded up.The New Standard----------------The Skirvin will now set the new standard for hotels in the downtown OKC area. When you walk in the front door you feel as if you have stepped back into the early 1900's to a brand new hotel - now with all modern ameneties.As I checked in I could feel the attitude towards impeccable service that the staff were taking. Even though I was being assisted by one gentlemen I was introduced to the other two at the front desk. This was done for everyone that checks in.There was hotel staff in the lobby just to assist with questions and comments. The check in process was quick, effecient and warm. I almost felt like I was checking into a B&B.As I wandered to my room I could not help but take in the commitment to the restoration and the quality of the workmanship throughout the facility.I was overly impressed as I walked into the room. The furnishings were wonderful and it felt like an apartment. The bathroom was very modern with a a walk in shower and a mirror that does not fog.The Caveat - Please remember I do ALL my corporate hotel stays with Hilton so the pictures of the room below are from a suite that I was upgraded to because of status.However, I did have an opportunity to view a standard room as a maid was servicing it and that room had very similar appointments.Cocktail Hour-------------It was time to head to the Red Piano Lounge. Yes they do have a Red Piano. On this evening a guitar player was strumming and incredible array of music that kept the bar upbeat.The service continued to be Stellar and the prices for cocktails were not unreasonable. Beer: $4.25 avg. Cocktails: $7-10 avg.--------------The remodel and impeccable service has kept the Skirvin to its heritage and I can say that I have a new hotel to stay at in OKC.
review_content_40: Beautiful place!  Rooms, hallways, accommodations are great!  Plus, I have used this hotel for OKC bachelorette parties, the room was a bit pricey, but you get a comp stretch limo and you just tip the driver, goes anywhere in Bricktown. We took him to eat, back to hotel for festivities and then our, back in limo before 2 am and it feels like a lux party!  My brides loved it and so did I!  Parking you must pay for though bc it is downtown, only free is on the street which is non existent usually.  Great staff, although very proper, not stuffy, had no problem with out fun and kept everyone safe!Very nice hotel with above average service.  Comfortable, nicely decorated rooms.  Other than the loud HVAC fan, room was quiet and seemed well sound-insulated.  Stayed on 8th and 10th floors and nothing went "bump in the night" for me.  Lunch buffet is very good.  Food in the piano bar was ok at best; better just for a pre-dinner cocktail.The best Hilton property in the world!!!!!!! The staff is such a delight, always. There are staff whose parents worked here for fifty years. I love everyone I come across whom works for this hotel. From the front desk clerk who always hooks us up as diamond members to the maid in the hall. And then the maid in the next hall. They are all so awesome and you will have a delightful conversation with all of them. We stay here around three times a year for the past five years and it is always consistent. Thank you for being the best Hilton Skirvin!!!!!Great, old-world-feel hotel. Plushy towels in rooms and decadent bathrobes. Beds are comfy, although the rooms w 2 beds are only doubles, not queens as in other hotels. Overall a good experience. The ambiance is first-rate, if you're looking for classiness.Charming and nicely restored. Great staff. Big rooms with all modern amenities. Fourteenth floor meeting space is great. Walking distance to museums and bars and the arena. Too bad there is not more shopping. Stay here to get a flavor of turn of the century(19 to 20) Oklahoma.Had Sunday Brunch here; the service was mediocre and the food was substandard.  I ordered the Salmon burger but a Salmon Croquet was my burger - not expected from the menu description and the Croquet was underdone and under seasoned.  Been there twice, first and last for brunch.Recently renovated, this was easily the nicest hotel I've stayed at in a lonnnng time. I checked in late and left early so I don't have much to share but:The room? Clean & updated but I got a low-level floor with a view of a cement wall.The bed? Possibly the most comfortable hotel bed EVER. The valet? Totally freaking nice.I have the say the name is a bit odd - but yes, I understand the gentleman that originally built the hotel's last name is Skirvin... Other than that, this hotel was terrific!I'm on the road throughout the summer traveling for business and was not necessarily excited to be visiting Oklahoma City in the heat and humidity ... Hesitant on the hotel. What do I expect? Kept chanting "there's no place like home. there's no place like home..."To my surprise, the hotel is quite large, newly renovated, and pretty darn comfortable!  I had a wonderfully large room with a fluffy bed, new flat screen TV and extra large bathroom.  Even though I was only there for 1 night the girl likes to pack ... (and in my defense, was off to Austin for the remainder of the week) ;)So, if you find yourself in OKC -- for whatever the reason -- you may want to settle yourself into a spacious room at The Skirvin.  It won't disappoint.This was my first time visiting Oklahoma City, so I chose the hotel because of its central location.  I can't stress how impressed I am with the hotel.  The large room, nice bathroom with the deep bathtub, and the comfortable beds were very enjoyable to me, and the workout room had everything I needed.  I was very happy to see that everything in the hotel was new and clean, and that not an inch of the hotel went without renovation.  The pool here was very small, but the hot tub was large enough to fit five people.  Overall, I really enjoyed my stay at the Skirvin Hilton and in Oklahoma City.Very nice to see such a historic building in such beautiful condition!Difficult, unfriendly staff. Justin checked me in and came off poorly. Horrible attitude... Horrible customer service. My room smells like mildew. Room service would not serve me wine despite my request falling within the hours the menu states wine is available.The Skirvin Hilton looks great, but the details and lack of polish with the staff let it down. It doesn't help that Oklahoma City has an extremely boring downtown that literally empties out after 5:30PM, and there is absolutely nothing to do within 5 blocks of the hotel after dark (and not much going on in the dayltight either). The hotel is freshly renovated, nicely furnished, and not quite as blandly corporate as the usual downtown Hilton would be. They did the nicest job on the small but elegant lobby, bar and restaurant. Sinatra playing in the elevators, and lots of old photos on the walls gives it a snazzy touch. And yet, the facility is let down by its staff. The staff overall was not rude, not disastrous, and yet clearly not polished or profesional enough, especially for the prices charged in their elegant looking hotel. The Valet/Doormen staff out front were the worst and sloppiest; and they all need to be sent to the barbershop, told to shave every day, taught some manners, and told to not lean around talking about parties and ballgames and ignoring their guests entering and exiting the hotel. The bar staff, restaurant staff and front desk staff were only marginally better, but the polish expected from this level of hotel is just not there. The staff of the Skirvin Hilton is definitely not ready for prime time, but for a Howard Johnson's near the airport they'd be great. As for Oklahoma City nightlife.... if your idea of a big Saturday night is going to eat at a Hooter's or Rib Palace (6 blocks away) or a stinky college-kid party bar in Bricktown (5 blocks away), then OKC is just for you! Otherwise, there is nothing within walking distance of the Skirvin for meals or anything else. The nearest Starbucks is almost a mile east of the hotel, which should give you an indication of how welcoming the neighborhood is around the Skirvin. Be prepared for many vacant storefronts and abandoned streetscapes around this hotel. And don't expect the Skirvin doormen to do much as you approach the front door, either.I stayed at the Skirvin Hilton 3 weeks ago while in town for an advertising competition.  Upon check-in I was required to put down a credit card for incidentals, but was assured it was just a formality as the room would be paid for by the head of our group upon checkout.  I ordered no room service and did not charge anything to my room and when we left, my adviser assured me that he had paid for all the rooms for our group.Last week, my American Express bill arrived and lo and behold, the Skirvin had charged me $360 for 2 nights in my room.  I double-checked with my adviser that he had paid for my room and he emailed me the confirmation number he received when we checked out.  After 3 days of calling and leaving 5 voice mails without any response, I was forced to contact American Express to file a dispute.  Bottom line, the customer service is terrible and it made me forget all the positives of staying at the hotel.  Not that I plan to return to Oklahoma City, but if I ever have to, I will NEVER stay at the Skirvin Hilton again.Some things were fine, however the valet wouldn't help us take in our luggage, rude, and lacking in professionalism. This is the second time I one month where we had a similar issue. Definitely not a one time experience. Management called to apologize but didn't really make us feel like the problem was resolved.I stayed here 2 weekends ago for my first visit in Oklahoma City.  I have to say, it exceeded my expectations in every way.  First, the staff was top notch.  We got there around 10 pm on a Saturday night, and there was a lot of staff on hand to help check us in, get off to our room, and direct us to the nightlife around town (which there is quite a bit).  We returned back to the hotel a couple hours later, and remarked to the staff at the front desk how grand and impressive the original hotel must have been, since it is evident that a lot of money was used to preserve this place.  So they offered a few comments, and then asked if we'd like a personal tour...at midnight on a Saturday.  Being architecture geeks, I couldn't say no - and off we went around the building.  Go to the 14th floor and check out the rooms and views yourself and you'll see what I mean.Anyway - this place is awesome.  Really makes Oklahoma City probably one of the most underrrated downtowns in the US.  I came to the City with no idea what to expect, and really thought there's a lot going on.  Oh - and be prepared for crowds and getting a bit dressed up - most places around won't let you in if you grunged down.This is the hotel my parents had their honeymoon in! The owners have done a great job restoring it. You feel like your walking into a true treasure in downtown OKC. The lobby is beautiful! Go into the bar and grab a drink and listen to the piano. I attend a luncheon here once a month and the rooms are great, the staff is professional, and the food is tasty for mass food!I stay here everytime I'm in OKC, which is about every 3 months.  The ambiance and decor is rich, luxurious and makes me feel like I am back in the victorian era (not really good on my historical decor, so work with me on this!).  The beds are super comfortable and the hotel staff has always been friendly and overly helpful, with the exception of two girls who work the front desk in the morning.  I must catch those 2 ladies on a bad morning everytime I'm there!  This is the only reason I gave the hotel 4 stars instead of 5.  Otherwise, everything else is fantastic!  (Oh, with the exception of the usual Hilton Crabtree & Evelyn tolieties.  Hilton, these smell like cheap old lady!!  Get something new!!)Nicely renovated historic hotel.  Very friendly, smart, knowledgeable staff.  I requested a view; they obliged with a good city view including the state capitol.  I love the old photos in the hallways.  Not sure how I feel about the mix of old and new (some of the hallway furniture seemed oddly modern juxtaposed with the other elements).this is a great spot down town OC.. Old building but with great upgrades... Hotel staff has stories about this place being haunted.. really good service for sure... this is defintly a upscale hotel.... outstanding resturants within walking distance if you valet your car,,This hotel, finally restored and reopened after nearly 20 years of sitting vacant, is immaculate.
